  4. I bought this in May 2012 and still use it almost daily.<br />I must have dropped it 100 times and it's still scratch free. The hook sticks so well, that I had to leave it at my old apartment but getting a replacement at Home Depot is pretty cheap.<br /><br />The anti-fog thing really works. Just holding it under water for a few seconds gives me more than enough time to shave.<br /><br />Seriously, the best $10 you will ever spend.   10. I bought the larger size for my shower at home. Follow the simple directions and it absolutely works! I recently purchased this smaller size for when I travel again. I definitely recommend this fog free mirror.

  12. It's pretty straight forward. It's nothing special like using hot water or anything like that. Just heat it up under the water and you're good for a shave.
  13. Just something very simple to use. Make sure you follow directions and put it in an optimal spot.   14. Having this mirror allows you to shave in the shower thus saving time in getting ready for work. Wish I had purchased a long time ago!
  15. Gosh...I really like this mirror. It is the perfect size to hold in my hand. I just pull it down from its hook, run it under water, shave with it in my hand, and after my shower is done, I dry it with the towel before I hang it back up (no water spots to deal with that way). It just works.<br /><br />I just don't understand some of these negative reviews. One guy said it was \\"too expensive for just a plastic mirror with a hole\\". Um...it is like nine bucks, and has a convenient hook system that comes with it. Sure, you can probably buy a plastic mirror for $3.97 at your local crap-mart, and it will be a piece of junk with no hook. Is the extra $5 for this one really a burden??<br /><br />Another several reviews talked about water droplets. HELLOOO? We are shaving in the shower. What magic mirror have you used that neither fogs nor gets water on it when immersed in water? I can't say that i've EVER had an issue with the water droplets, but for those that do, there's this great product called Rain-X. Maybe try that.<br /><br />Another reviewer said his adhesive hook fell down. Seriously? You are gonna admit to everyone that you are either sloppy (ie didn't clean the surface) or just a fool because you can't make adhesive stick? Have any of you EVER had those \\"foam-style\\" adhesives not stick...those things are like super glue.<br /><br />This is exactly what I wanted. A simple, no frills plastic mirror with some type of mounting system...for cheap! It just works. How does it get any better? Oh, I can tell you. It gets better because if you read those negative reviews, there's obviously a real, live, human guy who owns the company and who cares about his product and true customer satisfaction (and he will attempt to contact you if you've had any problems). Try getting that at crap-mart.
  16. Good for what is it. It does fog up, but you rinse it with water to clear it. But it is not able to be relocated once you stick it up
  17. Easy to mount on wall and provides nice clear image for shaving. Simple thing made well. Will update re. durability esp. with outdoor use.<br /><br />September 2012: a year on and it's still in great shape. Simple thing made well.<br /><br />September 2013: still in good shape. Have one in the bathroom shower and it's doing fine as well.<br /><br />As for the fog-free claim, well, not so much, but there really is no such thing, and its virtues make up for any shortcomings.
  18. Like most other reviewers here, I have been disappointed in the past with mirrors that claimed to be fog-free but that would only stay that way for a couple of weeks at best. On the other hand, I have been using this mirror almost two months and it is just as fog-free as when I got it.<br /><br />UPDATE: I dropped my review from five to four stars because after a while, the mirror got hazy and I was unable to restore it to its original clarity even with toothpaste. Still, for the price the mirror lasted about a year, maybe more, which is much longer than any other shaving mirror I've used in the past.<br /><br />Actually, the mirror does get fogged--however, unlike other shower mirrors, this one has a small slot cut out in its upper center portion that allows it to be hung on the included adhesive hook. When it does fog up, you simply remove it, run it under your shower water for a second or two, and place it back on the hook--and it's good to go for 3-5 more minutes. I recently started shaving in the shower and I do 2-3 passes, and I've found that one rinse is good enough for an entire pass. So, a quick rinse between passes is all I need to get a babyface. This not only saves time, but cuts down on the razor irritation, nicks and cuts as well. This mirror is also ideal for washing your face. I use a facial cleanser in a tube and this mirror helps me get a nice even lather all over my face and keeps me from missing any spots.<br /><br />The hook included with the mirror is easy to install and it's very sturdy--it has not budged since I put it up.<br /><br />If you have a small shower and/or stuff all over the place inside it, this mirror won't cause too much crowding. I'm not sure offhand what the dimensions are, but it's just big enough for my face and doesn't take up much room at all.<br /><br />Another reviewer commented about water spots. They do accumulate over time, but the directions suggested cleaning them with toothpaste, which works like a champ. It made my spotted mirror look brand new again.<br /><br />Oh, and one other thing, just to echo other reviewers: there is a strip of plastic covering the mirror that needs to be removed before use. It's a bit tricky to get a purchase on, and you might think you're removing something that's supposed to be there. Once you get a hold of it, though, it comes off pretty easily.
  19. It is wonderful.....it really works and it's safe for my grandaughter when she visits, she loves it. My husband uses for shaving, said it really works well. I liked the price.AMAZON RULES if AMAZON DOESN'T HAVE IT YOU CAN'T BUY IT, THAT GOES FOR EVERYTHING I LOOK FOR
  20. Great little mirror! Works just as described. Make sure the protective coating is removed and hold it under the water for a few seconds and that's it. I like that it's acrylic, which makes it really light and safe if dropped.
  21. the mirror is very small, not much larger than a compact mirror.. it is fog free as long as you keep re-wetting it.
  22. Like several other reviews, I was kind of surprised at the small size (probably because I didn't pay any attention to the dimensions in the product description), but upon climbing in the shower in order to decide where to mount the hook, I quickly discovered that it is just the right size for the task at hand (unless for some strange reason you like to stand 3 feet away when shaving)! My shower is the type that is located in a tub enclosure, so after trying out a couple of placements I decided to mount it at the opposite end of the shower head. This works out just great since all I have to do is make a 180 degree turn and I can shave without having the shower stream interfere with the view of my handsome mug! I also really like the design of this item compared to all the competition. It is total simplicity. But after reading reviews on 6 or 7 other allegedly fog free mirrors I came to see that in this particular case simple is much more practical than complicated (and expensive). As advertised, it stayed fog free after holding it under the shower stream for 3-4 seconds! Lastly, I must mention the incredible customer service that this company offers with this product. Shortly after ordering this item I received an e-mail from a representative of the company thanking me and telling me about the product, and how to get started by removing the protective cover. Never in my life have I seen or heard of such amazing customer service, and certainly would not have expected in my wildest dreams to receive it from a $10 purchase! Bravo and Kudos to the Cumberland Company!! I wish they made more things because I would definitely buy from them!!!
  23. I had read other reviews about the size of the mirror. Not sure what others are talking about but the mirror size is perfect for the shower. Simply run the mirror under the water as directed and no fog! Many times I don't even have to run water over it before I shave. I think this is a great product and would recommend it to anybody.   24. I really, really hate shaving. When I'm not out of town on business trips I won't shave at all. I hate being scruffy and unshaven but I really hate standing there in the cold trying to shave too. Shower mirrors make this process much easier. Unlike other shower mirrors this does not attach to the water line, nor does it have an anti-fog coating (these generally start to peel off after a few uses). It becomes fog free by holding the mirror under hot water for a few seconds. This keeps the mirror fog-less long enough to shave. I think that this anti-fog method is likely the most effective, its also the least expensive.

  26. The mirror is indeed very small. But we got this for our 7 year old so he can see himself and check his hair as he is shampooing. (He tends to miss parts of his hair when he is shampooing.) The mirror is crystal clear and fogless. However, the only reason I give it 3 stars is because it does NOT stick to the wall. It comes with something similar to the 3M hooks, but it's the dollar store kind and the hold on it is not good. If you want this to stick to the wall you will need to go buy a 3M hook. But I think it's worth it, if this mirror is what you are looking for.

  29. Acrylic mirror with plastic hook plus adhesive strip. You just hold it under the water to heat it up and it stays fog-free long enough to shave. Not huge, but size is adequate for shaving.   30. I bought this for my very picky husband. He regularly shaves in the shower, and likes having a mirror. He's bought several (many?) mirrors over the years - including at least one that cost close to $100. None worked. I decided that, for the $10 this one cost, it was worth a try. He (and I) were pleasantly surprised. This one works well. I did have to convince him to be patient enough to run it under the hot shower water for a few seconds, (maybe up to 10 seconds?) so that it could become, and stay, fog free. As they say, it works on basic science (fog is condensation and is drawn to cooler surfaces - warm it under the shower and no fog). While he initially wasn't excited about that part, I was able to convince him that it was worth the (minimal) time - and certainly less time than he used to spend spraying things that didn't work on mirrors in an attempt to restore coatings that didn't work. Several reviewers have commented on the small size. My husband has a 'less than small' face - and once he got used to the mirror size admitted it wasn't an issue for him at all. It adheres well to our ceramic tile shower. Definitely recommend this mirror -

It should take under a minute to mount the mirror. The reason why the mirror uses a hook is that you are supposed to run the mirror under the hot water, to equalize the temperature and eliminate the fogging. And it works exactly as promised. It looks nice, too, and the price is very reasonable, so this is the perfect solution to shaving in the shower.

  103. Ok so ... at first I wasn't too thrilled with the mirror and actually wrote a review here reflecting my dissatisfaction. But within about an hour, I received a nicely worded email from the manufacturer offering insight to exactly how the technology in the mirrors construction, makes it truly fogless. We had it positioned in the shower too high on the wall (have kids so ... glass and water + kids = not good).<br /><br />I've posted this info below but I gotta say .... any company that is that willing to stand behind their product and offer such personal customer service is a 100% winner in my book. If only all online retailers could be this way. It's nice to know they care enough to respond personally. Buy the mirror ... it's affordable and does what it says. Enjoy! :)<br /><br />From the email I received .......<br /><br />If I may, please allow me the opportunity to share how the mirror works in an attempt to help alleviate the fogging issues you mentioned in your review.<br /><br /> Most houses are kept in a temperature range of 70-75 degrees.<br /> The average shower water temperature is 107.5 degrees.<br /> Fog on a mirror is simply condensation. The air in the bathroom is heated by the shower and becomes saturated with moisture.<br /> When this saturated moist hot air comes in contact with the shower shave mirror (which is still at normal room temperature roughly 30 degrees less), the moisture comes out of the air and condensates on the shower shave mirror surface.<br /> When you hold you Shave Well mirror under the shower stream for a few seconds, the acrylic mirror will warm up allowing for the temperature of the moist air and the mirror itself to equalize.<br /> Once you have held the mirror in the shower spray to equalize the temperature of you shower and the mirror, there can't/won't be any fog/condensation.<br /><br />All of that being said, the mirror works on basic science. If your mirror is still fogging then the only answer I can give you is that it remains cooler than the temperature of the shower. Since the mirror is rather thin acrylic, it should warm up in the few seconds you have been holding it in the warm water of the shower spray.<br /><br />Some additional thoughts that remain would be<br /><br />a.) Whether or not you have a greatly reduced flow shower head. If you do, it may take longer for enough warm water to equalize the temperature of the mirror.<br /><br />b.) If the mirror hung so high that there is a direct flow of cool air over the shower curtain/door or whether an air conditioning vent is blowing toward it. If this is the case, I am happy to send you a new hook so that you can reposition the mirror.<br /><br />c.) One additional suggestion would be to make sure you are turning both the front and back of the mirror under the shower water spray when you are equalizing it. This will help in \\"warming it up\\" to equalize the temperature.<br /><br />Finally, regarding the issue of the size of the Shave Well mirror, it was designed to be removable from the wall to truly address the issue of fog by \\"warming up\\" the mirror under the shower. Given that the mirror will be removed from the hook before you shave, many users choose to hold the mirror while shaving. The 6\\" X 4\\" size fits well in a users hand as well as provides a complete reflection of the entire face while shaving.<br /><br />To avoid any confusion, under the Product Description section of the amazon.com listing is the size of the item is shown: \\"The Shave Well Company fog free shower shave mirror measures 4\\" wide, 6\\" tall and is 1/8\\" thick. The base of the adhesive hook (the part that sticks to the wall) measures 1\\" wide and 1 1/2\\" tall.\\"u is that it remains cooler than the temperature of the shower. Since the mirror is rather thin acrylic, it should warm up in the few seconds you have been holding it in the warm water of the shower spray.<br /><br />Some additional thoughts that remain would be<br /><br />a.) Whether or not you have a greatly reduced flow shower head. If you do, it may take longer for enough warm water to equalize the temperature of the mirror.<br /><br />b.) If the mirror hung so high that there is a direct flow of cool air over the shower curtain/door or whether an air conditioning vent is blowing toward it. If this is the case, I am happy to send you a new hook so that you can reposition the mirror.<br /><br />c.) One additional suggestion would be to make sure you are turning both the front and back of the mirror under the shower water spray when you are equalizing it. This will help in \\"warming it up\\" to equalize the temperature.<br /><br />Finally, regarding the issue of the size of the Shave Well mirror, it was designed to be removable from the wall to truly address the issue of fog by \\"warming up\\" the mirror under the shower. Given that the mirror will be removed from the hook before you shave, many users choose to hold the mirror while shaving. The base of the adhesive hook (the part that sticks to the wall) measures 1\\" wide and 1 1/2\\" tall.\\"

  112. This is a simply mirror that comes with one of those white hooks that you peel the back off of to hang. The mirror has a gray back-side which I assume is meant to be sensitive to temperature? The premise is good I suppose. Why do mirrors fog in the shower? Because they are cold and collect water vapor / steam and condensation. The idea is that this mirror heats up quickly by running it under the hot shower water? First problem: I don't have an extra hand to hold the mirror under the hot water in the shower, because I'm using both hands to wash myself. So, my answer was to take the mirror off the hook and set it on the ground in the shower so the \\"runoff\\" water would heat it up. Second problem: If you get the mirror warmed up so it won't collect steam / condensation, it only stays heated up for a very short time (not long enough for me to shave before it starts steaming over again). Third problem: if I set the mirror on the floor of the shower to heat up, it collects soap scum and such very quickly (due to being exposed to runoff water). My assessment: I wasted my money on this product and I should have either bought a better made mirror (perhaps with a suction cup to hang it so I can move where it's hanging) and deal with the steam, or I should have bought one of the more expensive mirrors that use an actual source water source to heat up the mirror.<br /><br />NOTE: Initially I gave this product 1 star, but I have since changed it to 3 stars. As others have noted, this seller really believes in his product, and that counts for something. Also, I'm still using it after some time now, so it can't be all THAT bad. I really think the problems I experienced are the particularly cold initial temperature in my shower. The science here isn't revolutionary (warm up the mirror, less condensation), but the basics of it are sound. I just have to keep \\"re-warming\\" periodically while I shave.
  113. A fog free shower mirror that actually works! Granted, it will only stay fog free for 2-3 minutes before you have to hold it under the water for a few seconds again, but still... I only have to \\"re-de-fog\\" it once during my shave. It's quite durable, as well. It's not glass, but rather some kind of plastic. If you have a poorly lit shower, like me, I suggest getting one of those little waterproof, battery-operated tap lights, like [[ASIN:B0017KYDZA this]] one and putting on the shower wall directly under your mirror. Just make sure you check the dimensions of this mirror before you order and that you are satisfied with the size. I do think it could have been a bit larger, but I am still extremely pleased with it. So... Pros: Durable, Lightweight, Easy to Install, Easy to Clean, Actually Works, Affordable Cons: A Tad Small

The whole surface is covered with water spots and they don't go away. Perhaps if you want to really work hard, you could warm it up, and then squeegee it. Too much work for me.   123. This product does exactly what it says. I'm very pleased and I would highly recommend it to others. Before you use it, just let the shower water run on each side of the mirror for a few seconds, and it stays very clear and fog-free for many minutes! The mirror is very light but also very hardy--I accidentally dropped it, but it stayed perfectly intact and without any cracks or scratches. After a month, the hook suddenly fell off, but it was probably my fault because I didn't thoroughly clean the wall tile before I adhered the hook onto it. I contacted the product's customer service with a request for a replacement hook, and Bill Vogel (Exec VP) responded within 24 hours, saying that he'll immediately send a new hook, and he provided very helpful tips regarding how to properly clean the wall, and how to keep the mirror clear (e.g., to polish it with a little wd-40 so that water droplets don't stick). I received the replacement hook just a few days after shipment at no cost to me, and Bill included our email correspondence. Overall, I love this product, and the customer service is the best I've ever experienced. Thank you very much!

  153. I researched fogless shower mirrors a fair bit before purchasing this one. The basic reason for fog, as one quickly finds out, is condensation due to temperature difference. There are thus a few different ways of solving the problem. One is for the mirror to be electrically heated. Another is a hot water bank behind the mirror. Another is a special coating on the mirror to attempt to slow temperature changes and condensation. This mirror uses the simplest method possible, namely it hangs on a hook and you take it off and run it under the hot water. I believe it is very effective. Some people comment on its size. That has never been a problem for me. In fact, because it's small enough, I would even consider bringing it on trips with me so I can shave in hotel showers.
  154. I used the Shave Well Company Truly Fog Free Shower Shave Mirror for the first time today. Once the protective coating is removed, the mirror is crystal clear. I think the size is just right, at least for me, and it is easy to securely grip the mirror due to the soft, rubber-like backing. While it didn't stay fog-free for the entire shower, it was easy to hold it under hot water for a few seconds just before I was ready to shave and it stayed fog-free for the shave. I'm pleased that I purchased this mirror and anticipate many years of usage.
  155. I bought this for my boyfriend because he likes to shave in the shower. I had bought a fancier one for him for christmas which mounts right one to the wall, but you cannot take it down or move it. We moved about a month ago an could not take our other one with us without damaging it or the bathtub wall. I bought him this one, it's smaller but it works well, all you have to do it run it under the hot shower water for a few seconds, maybe up to 10 seconds and it stays fog free for quite a while. He also said that he likes the fact that you can take it off and move it around, that way you can be sure that you didnt miss anywhere! All in all, great fog free shower mirror, for a great price!

  157. Bought one of those great \\"goose neck\\" showerheads on Amazon and just as I was closing out, saw the ad for the shower mirror. Took a chance because it was really inexpensive. Even if it didn't work, I wouldn't lose much. I was disappointed with the size of the mirror, however after using it, it became apparent that a bigger mirror would do nothing but reflect stuff you don't need to see. What you need to see is your face and neck - period. I had never shaved in the shower before and what I love about it is there is absolutely no clean up! I used to get water all over the sink. Not a big deal to clean this up, but shaving is such a pain, anything that makes it easier is a plus. I followed the directions to mount the hook, but the mirror fell off after about a day or two. I reapplied it with a small drop of Krazy glue. It won't come off again. I have no concern about hard water spots on the mirror - I just spray it with distilled water after my shower, just as I do with my glasses - the water rapidly air dries spotlessly without any rubbing. I turn it to face the wall prior to spraying Clean Shower.

The mirror is rather small at 4x6 inches. Although the size is listed in the description I overlooked that when I placed my order and was quite shocked once the mirror arrived. The diminutive size does cause a few problems as the mirror sometimes fogs up from my breath when holding it too close to my face. A larger mirror would have alleviated this problem. Another issue is that the mirror does show water spots after drying, supposedly this can be eliminated by polishing the mirror with toothpaste, but I have not tried this. Overall a nice mirror that I can see myself using for quite a while, but it is not without it flaws.

  185. Don't let my review title fool you. If you follow the directions, it works just as it says it does. I've been using this for about a week now and used that time to figure out how it works. Just like the box says, you run it under your shower stream for a few seconds and there is no fog on the mirror surface. However, the fog only stays away for so many minutes. I figured out that the higher the water temperature you place the mirror under, the longer the fog stays away. If the fog does come back, just put the mirror under the water again and you're back in business. So yes, you MAY have to run it under the water a few times during your shower, but it all depends on how long it takes you to shave. The included hook works well for this mirror. Even though you might have to run the mirror under the water a few times, a few seconds is well worth the convenience of shaving in the shower.
  186. It is not as small as I though when reading other reviews (not really big, but enough for shaving). But maybe I take longer than average shaving ;-)

  220. I have used many shower shaving mirrors before, all disappointing, but this one really lives up to its claims. Most of the others mounted to the shower wall, and they'd fog immediately. I'd end up trying to \\"throw\\" water at them to get them to clear up, but the fog and streaking would immediately reappear. Those mirrors weren't heavy-duty enough to hold the heat, which is the trick. This mirror's heavy duty surface is what retains the heat when held under the shower, and the quality of the reflection is first class. I've gotten into the habit of holding the mirror in one hand and shaving with the other. That way, I can quickly re-heat the mirror if needed, but more importantly, realign my face and mirror for the best lighting and focal distance. I haven't had to polish the mirror with toothpaste yet, but the other mirrors all warned me not to clean them with anything, as it would wreck their special coatings. This mirror's design doesn't rely on \\"special\\" coatings that don't work anyway, and allows for you to restore the surface with a gentle abrasive (toothpaste) when and if needed. I even received an email from the president (OK, I'm sure it was a form letter) making sure I knew how to use it and that I was satisfied. That's First Class! The hardest part for me was trying to get the protective plastic coating off of the surface of the mirror when I opened the package. I love this mirror. I travel a lot, and think I'll buy another to keep in my travel bag with my travel toiletries so I can enjoy a nice shave in the hotel showers, too.

That's exactly what happened - I quickly received the replacement and a followup, and sure enough the replacement isn't affected by the same issue the first one was. I'm impressed that for such a small/simple item, this company goes far beyond what I would expect in terms of customer service, and they really stand behind the quality of their product. The fog-free mirror is as advertised, too - you just run it under the shower for a few seconds, and it easily stays clear for long enough for a nice shave.

  241. This little mirror works very well and works exactly as the manufacturer describes. Because this mirror hangs from a hook (rather than a suction cup), it never falls or slides down the shower wall. If for some reason the included sticky hook doesn't work on a shower surface, I imagine that one could use another kind of hook purchased from a local hardware store (this was not an issue I faced--the included hook stuck and is still sticking well to a fiberglass shower insert). The mirror may be a bit smaller than one would expect by looking at the product page, but it reflects clearly and shows all that anyone would need to shave their face. A quick rinse of the mirror on both sides with warm or hot shower water gets rid of fogging, making this a convenient, lightweight mirror that is perfect for daily shaving.
  242. PERFECT! I went online to find a substitute for my mirror with suction cups that wouldn't stay up. I did WAY too much searching through reviews and thought I'd have to pay a bunch for what I wanted to have one that stayed up. Not so. This one is exactly what I'd hoped for. Easy Easy Easy. Works Works Works. And the price is what it should be for something like this.
  243. This mirror does not stay fog free. It is supposed to adapt to the amount of fog in your shower area and remain clear after that, but this does not happen. I had to splash water on it every 20 seconds for it to remain clear. It is worthless.
  244. This works using a very simple concept. If the mirror is the same temp as the water in your shower, it won't fog.<br /><br />Ironically when my [[ASIN:B000I7D2L4 Zadro Z300 Wall Mountable Fog Free Mirror]] stopped working right, I would pull it off the wall, but because of the design, it was a pain to remove.<br /><br />This is simple. Hook off, run mirror under water for 5 seconds, done.<br /><br />Sometimes you end up with some water left on the mirror, but you just have to adjust the angle when you run it under the water. NOT a big deal at all.<br /><br />Great product, great price and will work forever. There is NO fog free coating hocus-pokus to worry about.
  245. To me, there is no better way to shave then in the shower. I mean, who wants to go the ritual of filling the sink and making another mess? I've bought a few so-called &#34;fog free&#34; mirrors, even from elite mail order sites which degraded over a short time, but this product has my vote for simplicity and cleanliness. The suction cup has held to our shower tile continuously over time. Being so light weight, it easily travels. I've taken it on cruises and to hotels to enjoy shaving in a long, hot showers on their dime! This is a very together US business with a philosophy of quality and customer support.

  247. I love a good design. Simple yet functional. No suction cup - just an unobtrusive hook that stays put, and a small mirror that is the perfect size. Stays fog free long enough for me to shave. If you are a shower shaver, and you're tired of those bulky over-priced suction cup deals, I highly recommend the Shave Well mirror.<br /><br />UPDATE 10/03/2012:<br /><br />I've been using this mirror now for 6 months or so and wanted to add a few thoughts. While the mirror does stay fog free for a good while, I find that I usually will need to re-wet the mirror again about 1/2 way through my shave. Maybe I'm taking too much time to shave. Also, there are a lot of water spots, even right after warming up the mirror. I saw a suggestion to rub a small amount of toothpaste on the mirror and then rinse to reduce the water spotting, but that didn't really help much. Of course this could be due to the hardness of my water or something like that.<br /><br />What I've started doing is after I warm up the mirror under the shower, I give it a light spray with one of those \\"Daily Shower Cleaner\\" sprays. This eliminates the water spots and keeps the mirror completely fog free for the entire duration of my shower. The drawback: what ever chemicals are in this spray seem to be reacting with the backing of the mirror because I can see some deterioration along the edges of the mirror. No big deal to me, because it's inexpensive enough and I can just replace the mirror once a year or so.<br /><br />In conclusion, I think it's still the best option for a shower mirror.
  248. I saw earlier reviews that people were surprised at how small it seemed, but I did not have the same reaction. I had read the description so I knew what to expect. I like it, no bells or whistles, just a straight up simple mirror. For the money you can't beat it's functionality.

The advantage of this mirror compared to other \\"fog-free\\" mirrors is the ability to remove it from the hook and run it under the water. Probably not worth even the $10 it sells for here. Get a higher quality mirror is my suggestion.

Put them under very hot water for about 40 seconds so the mirror heats up then just hang on its hook and you can shave without the mirror fogging up - works just like advertised. You don't need reservoirs, batteries, piping, spray films, or any of the other solutions to the problem of mirror fogging. And it is PLENTY BIG ENOUGH for shaving, nose hair trimming, zit picking, or anything else you want to do in the shower.   260. Once upon, I had a water-resistant shower radio that had a flip up fogless mirror. The radio died, but I continued to use the mirror for shaving. I may not be very bright, but landing headshots on zombies is where I make my hay!
  261. My search for a fog free mirror is officially over.<br /><br />Simplicity is the key here. Attach the provided hook to the glass (better than attaching to tile) of the shower wall, and hang this mirror on it. When you're ready to shave, take the mirror off the hook and hold it under the running hot water for about five seconds. This makes the mirror the same temp as the water, and thus impossible to fog up (steam results from temperature differences between a surface and the air; if they're the SAME temp, it cannot form). It seems like a cheap trick to run it under water, because running water will wash away the fog from ANY mirror. However, because this mirror is thin, it retains the heat and remains at the water temp for quite some time. Other mirrors quickly cool off and form fog again. This one does not, at least not over the next five minutes. I guess if you left if hanging for 15 minutes fog would form again, but that's beside the point. If it takes you that long between your decision to shave and the actual act, then you need to enroll in a time management class.<br /><br />Complaints I have read re: Size. It is kind of small at 4\\" x 6\\". Having said that, it is PLENTY large enough to see my entire face to shave. Plus, even if it were not, I'm only shaving my lower face, and it is generous enough to show that. Unless your head is the size of Herman Munster's, you'll have plenty of room to see your ugly mug to remove that nasty hair and make yourself handsome again.<br /><br />Re: falling off the wall. Yeah, mine did that too. Simple fix is to use shower/tub clear silicone caulk ($5 at a hardware store), put a dab onto the back of the wall hook, stick to the shower glass and let it sit overnight, and you're done. It won't fall of again. So, this is a non-issue.<br /><br />I made mine even better by applying three coats of Rain-X (yes, the stuff you put on your windshield to force water beads to stay as beads instead of running together; if you do not own this product, you ought to because it's the very best automotive product I've used and does exactly what it says). With it applied, after I put the mirror under the water, the water that remains on the surface beads up nicely, so I am not looking through smudged water streaks trying to see my skin. It's a miracle product this Rain-X stuff. I use it on my car every month and don't even bother turning my windshield wipers on when it rains. That's how GREAT it is.<br /><br />So, if you follow the very simple instructions, it works. Best of all? It cannot fail, because there are no moving parts, no electric components, no pieces to fit together, etc. Run it under hot water and enjoy fog free shaving. That's all there is to it.<br /><br />If you get it and don't like it, return it. But if you don't like it, then the problem is likely with you and not this simple-to-use product that performs exactly as advertised. In my experience, that is very rare indeed.very best automotive product I've used and does exactly what it says). With it applied, after I put the mirror under the water, the water that remains on the surface beads up nicely, so I am not looking through smudged water streaks trying to see my skin. It's a miracle product this Rain-X stuff. I use it on my car every month and don't even bother turning my windshield wipers on when it rains. That's how GREAT it is. So, if you follow the very simple instructions, it works. Best of all? It cannot fail, because there are no moving parts, no electric components, no pieces to fit together, etc. Run it under hot water and enjoy fog free shaving. That's all there is to it. If you get it and don't like it, return it. But if you don't like it, then the problem is likely with you and not this simple-to-use product that performs exactly as advertised. In my experience, that is very rare indeed.

  276. This shower mirror is fogless is the same sense that whales can stay dry if they simply stay out of the ocean!   277. I bought this mirror to replace a little handheld one that I took from an LL Bean kit, but which went missing on my last move. It does exactly what it says it does. Small enough not to take up too much space, doesn't risk throwing shards of glass all over the shower floor if it does happen to fall, heats up quickly under the shower stream and stays clear long enough to shave. In that, it's a perfect tool. I don't know that I agree with the idea on the sticker, which is to use toothpaste to clean it. My toothpaste is a little abrasive, but I've always found that buffing the dry mirror against a towel does the job just fine. Good product, good price.
  278. Some of the negative reviews concerned me, but I bought this mirror anyway. I'm glad I did. The mirror no longer comes with any type of adhesive, so that is no longer a problem. [[ASIN:B001B1VWTA Command 17068 Medium Wire Hooks, 2 Hooks 4 Strips]] The comments about the mirror being too narrow are not correct - it is just fine. If you are having a rather hot shower with lots of fog, you need to run the mirror under the hot water for a little while first, then just shake the loose water off and I never have any problems whatsoever, I've had it for over a month now.

  287. The mirror is 6\\" x 4\\". Although I knew the size was smaller than I wanted from the description, it still gets the job done. I haven't tried cleaning it with toothpaste (see many of the comments sections), but will try that to decrease the water droplets that are unavoidable in a shower.<br /><br />I hung the shave mirror at a height where the hook was at my nose level. Give it some thought before you hang the mirror, because once its done, its done. Make sure you can comfortably get a good view of the areas you will be shaving, especially your neck.<br /><br />Things that could improve this item: The mirror includes 1 hook that has a glue backing. Including an extra one for someone who later decides that he hung the hook at the wrong height or has 2 showers would be a real bonus.   302. This mirror actually works!! I've tried different products in the past only to be annoyed or disappointed by suction cups or mirrors not actuallly fo free. I placed the mirror in the water for a few seconds to let it heat up. The mirror was absolutely fog free...and no suction cups!! My only issue was the adhesive strip that came with the mirror. I didn't want to place it on the shower wall only to be hard to remove later. Instead, I used one of those easy to move 3M strips I found around the house. No stress on the hook because the mirror is really light! Can't go wrong with this one!
  303. This is the best shower mirror we have tried. It still fogs up a bit but wipes easily with one swipe for a clear reflection. Hanger has not fallen off since we put it up.
  304. This mirror has been a lifesaver! I no longer have ridiculous irritation from shaving. My barber told me to start shaving in the shower and after research I settled on this mirror. I could not be happier with the mirror and will never shave again unless I'm in the shower.

  313. UPDATE<br />The Shave Well Company customer service responded very quickly to my talk with Amazon customer service and/or this review. I was shipped out two mirrors for the two defective ones that were shipped to me.<br /><br />Word of advice: if you have the mirror placed against tile then heat the tile up with hot water. This prohibits fog from developing as the tile is cold whereas the mirror is warm if you follow directions.<br />++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++<br />This product says what it tries to accomplish, be fog free. If does reduce the amount of fog it takes on; however, it is not truly fogless. A particular issue of concern is a defect in the product which results in what appears to be the backing of the mirror peeling off, as in bubbling of sorts.<br /><br />I would not buy this product again.

  315. I held off a little while on writing a review on this mirror because I have had several similar mirrors in the past that started off well, but quickly stopped being fog free. This little mirror truly is fog free and is the best of it's kind that I have had. You simply wet the front and back of the mirror when you get in the shower and you are good to go. It hangs on a little hook that sticks to the shower (like on of those command hooks with the sticky back). This has worked better than the suction cup type of hanger for me. My only wish is that it had a little hook for a razor, but I can't really even complain about that. It does just what it says it does. Well worth the money (actually it is pretty cheap, so probably more than worth the money)
  316. I love to shave in the shower and have been disappointed with past 'fogless' mirrors I've purchased. But this one is too simple to mess up. Hook sticks to the wall, mirror hangs on the hook. Just put both sides under hot water and you're set long enough to shave. Love it.

Just buy one. You'll use it every day.

  323. I've had this mirror for about a year and a half, and I'd have to say it's one of the best purchases I've made. I don't write many reviews (I should do more), so that alone says something about how satisfied I am with this product. Here's the gist:<br /><br />It works as advertised. All I need to do is hold it under the shower for 10-15 seconds, and it stays completely clear for at least 10 minutes - more than enough time for me. If I need even more, I just stick it back under;<br /><br />It's consistently provided a clear image - kinda critical when it comes to nick-free shaving. When it occasionally gets spotty - maybe every few months - I just rub a little toothpaste onto it (as directed by the manufacturer) with my fingers, rinse it off, and it's as clear as the day I got it;<br /><br />The size is perfect, at least for me. I worried, when I took it out of the box, that it would be too small. But I see my entire shaving area with my nose practically touching it, so it's large enough to get as close as I need to while still getting the &#34;big picture.&#34; But it's small and light enough that the adhesive hook stays put. It was frustrating to have to pick up my last mirror every time the suction cups gave out.<br /><br />That's it in a nutshell. I wish every product I purchased was as spot on and reliable as this one's been.
  324. Title says it all. This product works as advertised and meets my expectations. It doesn't fog and it's also easy to clean with a little toothpaste.
  325. This is literally just a hook you put on the shower wall and hang the mirror on it. This is truely fogless.   326. The mirror is very small and pretty cheap. It's basically a small piece of shaped plastic with a reflective coating on the rear. I noticed yesterday this reflective coating is already coming off in places. That means in a few months I'm going to have to toss this \\"mirror\\" and peel this hanger of the shower wall.<br /><br />Additionally, I would NOT exactly call this \\"Truly Fog Free\\". The instruction say to run the mirror under the water to prevent it from fogging up. Basically you heat the mirror to the temperature of the water and so long as it stays that temperature it will not fog. This method is true for any mirror. BUT, this mirror does still collect water droplets on the surface so you still can see the reflection all that well.<br /><br />I might buy this again if it cost 1 dollar and came with free shipping just so I didn't have to peel the hanger off the shower wall but that would be the only way.

  342. A few years ago I was gifted a shower shaving mirror and have been hooked on shaving in the shower ever since. As compared to the old shave-over-the-bathroom-sink method, the steamy shower environment really seems to make the shaving experience smoother, faster and much less painful.<br /><br />That first shower mirror was the type held to the wall by a couple suction cups... and those cups became hard and lost their grip in about six months. After that I tried a different mirror with four suction cups, and that one lasted about one year... actually had two of those in a row. Still, it would have been nice not to have had to purchase a replacement every nine to 12 months.<br /><br />A couple months ago I went looking for a longer-term replacement, and reviews of this Shave Well shaving mirror seems to indicate that it might be exactly what was needed. I made the purchase and would say that those reviews were right on the mark; am very happy with this item's functionality and mirrored surface, and offer the following for your consideration:<br /><br />* Following instruction, I cleaned the shower wall very well and then allowed more than the noted 1 hour for the wall to dry<br />* Mounted the mirror's hook on the clean wall and allowed the adhesion to bond overnight before hanging the mirror<br />* I shave near shower's end by applying shaving gel, running the mirror under the water, hanging the mirror, and shaving<br />* Putting the mirror under the water too early gave it time to cool, and fog returned. I now wait until ready to shave<br />* Before leaving the shower I'll shake the mirror to remove excess water, and might pat it once, not rub it, with the towel<br /><br />One thing I learned with the first few mirrors was how not to clean water spots from them... the first couple times I tried using dish soap and a scrubber sponge or a washcloth, and basically destroyed the mirrored finish on these things. None of the shower 'mirrors' I have owned have actually been made of a glass mirror; instead, they seem to be made by applying a thin mirrored finished to a plastic or plexiglass backing. That finish is fairly easy to damage, so some care is needed when trying to clean them.<br /><br />For whatever reason (maybe she read the instructions...) my wife suggested using toothpaste and that has worked quite well. For us, the paste type toothpaste works better than the gel type; we just apply a small dab or two, lightly rub the toothpaste around the mirror in small circles using the pad of our finger (not the fingernail), and then rinse it all off with warm water. Works amazingly well.<br /><br />After a few months use - so far, so good. This mirror has been excellent and easy to use. If you are looking for a mirror for use similar to what I've expressed above, and looking for a product that will do the job without breaking the bank, then I highly recommend this too you. If issues are experienced in less than a year, I will return to make appropriate updates.<br /><br />Highly recommendeden made of a glass mirror; instead, they seem to be made by applying a thin mirrored finished to a plastic or plexiglass backing. That finish is fairly easy to damage, so some care is needed when trying to clean them.<br /><br />For whatever reason (maybe she read the instructions...) my wife suggested using toothpaste and that has worked quite well. For us, the paste type toothpaste works better than the gel type; we just apply a small dab or two, lightly rub the toothpaste around the mirror in small circles using the pad of our finger (not the fingernail), and then rinse it all off with warm water. Works amazingly well.<br /><br />After a few months use - so far, so good. This mirror has been excellent and easy to use. If you are looking for a mirror for use similar to what I've expressed above, and looking for a product that will do the job without breaking the bank, then I highly recommend this too you. If issues are experienced in less than a year, I will return to make appropriate updates.<br /><br />Highly recommended

  345. I hate to give 5 stars until i have had the product for several years but i felt i had to offset some of the bad reviews. First, it is NOT a dull mirror. It has a film on it and you take it off. Looks like a mirror. If it looks dull and you pulled that off, return it and get a new one. Yes it takes prep to keep it from fogging as much, but is good for shaving. If a few drops are on the mirror, and that is bothering you, maybe you shouldnt try doing open heart surgery in the shower. Yes there are water drops on the mirror, but all im concerned about is seeing if im shaving the right areas. I don't think a few drops of water will make me end up accidentally slitting my throat because i learned to shave in front of a mirror that didnt have water drops so maybe i dont know what im talking about. However, if you are an adult, you should be ok with this mirror. It hangs up wherever you want, you have to run it under some water before using it, and as long as it doesnt take you 10 minutes to shave, it shouldnt be fogged up before you are done! If it holds up for more than 6 months, ill try and give it the 5 stars.

No, but following their instructions does keep it fog-free for a good 5+ minutes. After that, it only fogs up a touch towards the end of my shave, and even then that doesn't get in the way of my shave. If I need to, just letting the water from the shower run over it for a second or two takes care of any fog for the next 5 or so minutes. Highly recommended for those looking for a shower shave mirror.

  372. [[VIDEOID:mo23WHHWZNJOGLG]]The Shave Well mirror really works! I color my hair and when I return from the hair dresser I need to remove the color stain around my hair line. The easiest way to do it is in the hot shower. Before this little handy mirror I would just scrub blindly, now I can see where the scrubbing is needed so the job gets done much faster.<br /><br />I am attaching a collage of 4 photos that I will be referencing in this review.<br /><br />1. Photo #1: The mirror comes with a hook that you attached to the shower wall with a double sticky tape. I have a single piece shower stall to which it adhered very well. I have had the mirror in the shower for a week and it still solidly on. The mirror is very light so it does not put a lot of stress on the hook. I find the hook to be a more reliable mechanism than a suction cup, as those occasionally do come off. And I like that I can take the mirror off very easily.<br />2. Photo #2: The mirror comes with a protective film over the glass. The film is white and you cannot see through it. Once you remove it the mirror is very clear and the reflection is high quality.<br />The mirror is sized 6\\" by 4\\" and the glass has no magnification.<br />3. Photo #3: The mirror is very light, it weighs only 1.7 ounces<br />4. Photo #4: The back of the mirror is covered with thin thermal coating.<br /><br />Fog forms on mirrors because of condensation. The water in shower is warmer than the air in the house, it warms the air in the bathroom and condensates on any cool surfaces such as mirrors. If you hold this thin mirror under water for 10 seconds to warm it up condensation does not form on the glass until the mirror cools off. I measured that it stayed fog free for about 13 minutes, then a quick dip into the hot shower and it was fog free again.<br /><br />The best place to position the mirror is away from drafts that will quicken its cooling, and away from direct shower spray to minimize water spots.<br /><br />Overall I am very pleased with the mirror and recommend it.<br /><br />Ali Julia reviewvery pleased with the mirror and recommend it.<br /><br />Ali Julia review
  373. What a great value. This is the best shower mirror I've used. Pretty large field of view, nice and light, easy to rinse, pretty strong. I've dropped it a few times without apparent ill effect. After a month of use, the silvering on the mirror is starting to come off along the bottom edge, but it will have to get a lot worse to make any difference. At this price point, I'm very impressed.<br /><br />One word of caution--the included hanging hook is permanent and nearly impossible to remove. I placed it too low, and don't use it--instead, I use an inexpensive suction-cup hook, which I like better. That also makes it easy to travel with the mirror.
  374. Convenient little mirror, holding the mirror upright it is 4 inches in width and 6 inches in height. It is a little small but I really wasn't expecting anything more. It IS fog free but you need to warm up the mirror first so that it matches the temperature in the shower (this prevents condensation, also known as fog for most of you). The edges are a little sharp and I did end up cutting myself by mistake (I did apply quite a bit of force for this to happen, it's not like I just slid my finger against it and I was sliced). I'd recommend filing down the sides but then again you really won't be holding the mirror so no biggie. I only needed a small mirror so I could see which spots I missed when shaving, it's perfect.
  375. Excellent mirror. Not huge, but that's ok. It's super easy to clean, excellent reflection, and it does not fog at all. If it does, just hold it under the warm water for a moment and you're good!

  387. This mirror does stay fog free as long as it stays warm. I hold both front and back under hot water before hanging it on the wall. The problem is the material used. Since it is not glass, it doesn't retain heat very well. Some compromises had to be made for safety. Why doesn't anyone make something like this with a built-in battery powered heater element?<br /><br />I had a problem with the mounting hardware coming off the tile (my fault), but the company sent me replacement at no charge.   388. So this mirror is simple, inexpensive and works. I've used it to shave 4 times. It is a bit small to use as a hanging mirror, but its great for holding in your hand while you shave with the other. If you only have one arm then it would be tough. It doesn't fog up if you follow directions. Its simple. Run under the water for a few seconds. Then it won't fog up. The water does bead up real good on the mirror though and I have to wipe it off every once in a while to keep looking at myself when shaving. I have also used it to look for ticks in my nether regions. A good multi use mirror. I have dropped it and it didn't break so that is another good thing.   392. Both guys loved it and haven't even tried it yet. Smaller than expected but will travel well too. Good deal I think
  393. I got tired of the fogless mirrors I'd used in the past wearing out. Either the coating used to prevent fogging would stop working after a few months, or the suction cups used to hold it on the wall would wear out, or both. At first I was a little wary of the Shave Well, due to a few bad reviews regarding its small size and supposedly not being truly fog-free. But after seeing the worse ratings on more &#34;traditional&#34; fogless mirrors, and comments explaining how to properly use the Shave Well, I thought I'd give it a try. I figured that for the low cost I couldn't go too wrong. Well, I've been using it for a little over three months now, and I've got to say it works perfectly. Hold it under the stream of water for a few seconds on each side (as per the instructions), and it stays fog-free more than long enough for me to shave my face. Is the Shave Well small? Yes. But don't let its small size fool you. Even standing only a few inches away from it, it's _plenty_ big enough to see my whole face as I shave. And all else being equal, I'd rather have a smaller mirror than a larger one. As a bonus, its small size and light weight makes it practical for me to take with me when I travel, so I can shave in the shower wherever I am, something I'd wished I'd been able to do in the past. I've seen some other reviewers complaining about the fact that after you hold it under the water to warm it up there are beads of water on the surface, supposedly preventing them from being able to see well enough to shave. To that all I can say is that yes, a small amount of water beads on the surface, but not in a way that effects the use of the mirror _at_all_. I don't get what those other reviewers' problem was. It's simply not an issue. Anyway, the bottom line for me is that the Shave Well is exactly what I was looking for: a fog-free shaving mirror to use in the shower, that I should be able to use for years and years because it doesn't rely on a chemical coating that I know from experience will wear out. UPDATE - 7/24/2013: Well, it's been almost a year and a half of daily use now, and I still love it! My mirror's in perfect condition, no problems at all. UPDATE - 8/3/2014: Two and a half years of daily use, and still going strong! If it ever does wear out, I'll definitely buy another one. UPDATE - 8/13/2016: Going on five years of daily use, and still working great. A tiny amount of the reflective coating has worn off near the edges, but otherwise still like new.
  394. I use this to use in the shower for shaving my head with battery powered clipper. It works as expected without concerns about cracking glass in the shower. I wish they made a much larger size mirror- it is light enough that i suspect they could. Good for travelling as well.

  400. I've had this mirror for just over a year now.<br /><br />First, their support is great. I mean, it is a mirror, but when I contacted them to see if they could send another hook, as I mounted it too high, they sent a hook and a suction cup. I wound up losing the hook, after using the suction cup for a long time. I find there is much utility in being able to move the mirror around.<br /><br />Just recently, the backing has started to come off the mirror. At first, the mirror surface was not affected. Now, there is about a 1/8 inch gap at the bottom where there is no reflective area.<br /><br />The hook that it comes with is very permanent. I had a hard time getting it off, and decided to just leave it for the next tenets to deal with. The fog free claim has been hashed over a few times, but works pretty well. Rinse and shave. If the mirror is touching a cold surface, you are going to have to do this several times. I normally need to rinse the mirror once or twice per shave. The only way to get a fog free mirror is going to be by heating the mirror.

  402. Often, the best-designed things just work, as they say. They don't shout &#34;Look at me!&#34; or get dragged down with &#34;features&#34; or embellishments that no one really asked for. I wouldn't have thought to write a review of a shaving mirror, but I happened to see Amazon's profile of the family business and how they manufacture it -- with a non-profit that provides jobs for people with disabilities.   406. I bought this mirror for shaving in the shower after reading the other reviews.   407. I have owned at least 15 different kinds of shaving mirrors because I get a much closer shave in the shower vs standing at the sink. In all of these I had to either throw water to clear the mirror or use the anti-fog that did not last. Now this little mirror hangs on a hook and you just hold it under the shower and it's ready to go. I first thought the small size would be a problem but I can see fine and it takes up a lot less space. So for a good shave image in the shower this is the one for me.
  408. I was turned off by the designs requiring a water reservoir to be filled as I feel it will get scummy with time and be one more item that needs to be cleaned. The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is the way water will bubble on the mirror surface (think freshly waxed car).   413. Follow the instructions on this mirror and you'll absolutely be satisfied, I know I am. At the beginning of your shower hold it up to the hot water for about ten seconds (or so) so that the temperature of the material matches that of the water. This will prevent most, if not all fog buildup during the shower. Worst case scenario you easily remove it from the wall hook, rinse it for a second, and put it back. Although the mirror is small, you're not paying a lot for such a great product.<br /><br />Would buy again.

  415. I hemmed and hawed for a while before placing the order, but I decided to go with the smaller unit and see how it works. I've been using it a weeks now, and here is my take on it:<br />1) The size is fine. I was a little shocked when I saw how small it really was, but it's not an issue when you're actually shaving. After using it for the first time, I had no desire to order the larger one.<br />2) Fog-less: Yes it is. How much it is affected by fog is primarily a function of the ambient air temperature in the bathroom. During our hot Texas summer, I didn't even have to wet the mirror as the ambient air was somewhere around 78. Now that it's gotten cooler, the mirror does fog up if I don't wet it first. Running the back under the shower for a few seconds is usually all it takes.<br /><br />About the only issue I have is that the mirror is so light that exhaling makes it swing a little bit on the hook. Maybe I need to learn how not to breathe like a mule though. ;)

  419. This is, bar none, the best fog-free shaving mirror in the world. Having used dozens of them in the past, this is the only one that continues to work as intended. I have a larger one for home and the smaller one for traveling. If you're a guy and don't shave in the shower, you are missing the best shave of your life (with all the steam, water, etc...). But you need something light enough to hold in one hand (this mirror) while holding the shaver in the other. You can also use the enclosed hook if you don't want to hold it. Just remember to run water over it before using. This gets rid of any ambient temperature differences between the mirror and the air around it.<br /><br />When you first get it, there's a protective coating on the mirror side that is very hard to get off without using a knife (I don't have long fingernails). It would be great if it had a peel handle to remove the protective film as it took me five minutes to figure it out. In lieu of that, they could also put the letter B on the backside as both the front and the back look alike until you remove the film. I kept trying to remove the film from backside until I realized it was on the other side. Even then it took another five minutes to lift off the very thin protective film. I finally got out a steak knife to slip between the film and the plastic mirror.<br /><br />All in all this is the best shaving mirror you could possibly get, either small or large. Aside from that minor nitpicking, you won't go wrong.

  457. I used to use one of those bulky mirrors (with the suction cups to secure it to the wall and a small rack to hold shaving equipment). It is plastic and sort of felt like something they might give you to shave with in prison. But I decided to give it a try anyway.<br /><br />I had long been familiar with the science behind a heated mirror not fogging. I used to run water over my old mirror and it worked for a few minutes before fogging back up. The thin design of this mirror allowed for sustained fog free use. It's size is also perfect for holding while shaving. It's light weight so holding it is easy and if you drop it it doesn't sound like you dropped a pillowcase full of doorknobs into the tub.<br /><br />Also, because it has no real nooks and crannies, it doesn't develop mold as my old mirror did around creases and in between little crevices.<br /><br />Simple.   465. Nice quality mirror, well thought out packaging that includes everything needed for mounting. As long as you briefly warm it up in the water stream, it is completely fog free. Finally able to see what I'm shaving in the shower.
  466. Well its certainly not fog free. It fogs up all the time. I basically have to keep it under the shower water while I shave. The only good thing is that it dont stain like the other shower shave mirrors. Or at least so far.
  467. It's a low-cost product that does an OK job at first, but I left mine in the shower and the silver backing started coming away about six to eight months after purchase. I kept using it because at first it was just a nuisance, but eventually enough of the backing was gone that it became impossible to see anything.<br /><br />Would probably be a fine product if you planned to dry it off and remove from the shower every time, but I doubt most people do that. Probably better to find one with a more durable finish.
  468. Fogless yes. But once the water spots get on there this mirror is useless. Need to try a different one.
  469. Great product. Really works. The trick to get the water spots to run off easier is rub toothepaste all over it before you take a shower. It will stay completely clear with no fog or water droplets.
  470. I didn't think a fogless mirror was even possible. But this has been a great product, and my wife never yells at me for making a mess anymore.
  471. This products works as advertised. Nice size -- big enough to see, but not so big that you accidentally bump it all the time.<br /><br />My only gripe would be that the mirror isn't very clear in use because of the residual water on it. The best I've gotten so far is to wet it, then hold it edge-wise and whack it on my hand a few times. That knocks off most of the water, but it's not perfect. I could try Rain-X or something (that's next).<br /><br />I didn't use the supplied plastic hook; I just hang it on a razor hook thing I already had for the shower.
  472. Fog free?   473. My only issue is now I realize how poorly lit my bathroom is. The mirror works great, but it's hard to see my reflection due to lack of light (no fault of the mirror). And yes, it is fogless after you put it under the shower head for a little bit.
  474. Suppose I didn't read the details well enough. It's much smaller than I had thought. It gets the job done and doesn't fog up. I guess I'm just not wowed by it. It's really nothing special. Just a small mirrored piece of plastic that sticks to the wall with a command hook.
  475. At the price, the mirror is a bargain. It's not overly large, but does fit well in your hand and is big enough to see your whole face (unless you have either a giant face or are holding it inches away from where you're shaving). The &#34;fog free&#34; feature comes from heating up the mirror and I've found you need to heat it up every 2-3 minutes or so to keep it really fog free. I wish I could run it under water and get a full shave in without having to reheat the mirror (hence the 4 stars instead of 5), but other than that minor gripe it works well.
  476. Love it. I use it ever day

  479. I bought this to replace my current fogged up fog free mirror and love it. It does still fog up a little when I breathe while shaving which could become a problem but I've adjusted by taking more frequent breaks to rinse my razor and it's not a problem. In my experience, all fog free mirrors start out great and end up to where you can barely see in them but we'll see. I'm hoping I found one that'll last a while.<br /><br />For the price I don't think you could go wrong with this mirror. I did however replace the two sided tape provided with a 3M removable tape.
  480. Like all of these types of mirrors, I have to put water on it to keep it from steaming up. The manufacture states that it has to be positioned in a particular spot and used a particular way. Well that's not always applicable based on your shower/situation. I have a bathtub/shower and there's a window in it. I have only one spot to put the mirror, and the mirror fogs up whether the window is open or not. It works best when the window is cracked about 2&#34; and the steam can be pulled away from the mirror. Honestly, I don't ever expect that anyone will make one of these that works perfectly, but once I put water on this, it works longer than all the others I've had, and it gets me though my shave. Also, the water runs right off it when I first wet it and doesn't leave little droplets all over it, like all the other mirrors did. I also dry mine every time I get out of the shower to keep water spots from forming on it. I also like the little hanging tab for it, which has stayed stuck to my shower wall with no issues. And I like the hole in the mirror for hanging it, as it makes it easily removable so I can dry it.
  481. My facial hair grows pretty thick, and I'm not a daily shaver. So when I do shave, it becomes a bit of an ordeal. Because of all this, I've always preferred to shave in the shower.<br /><br />This mirror is an excellent product for my purposes. It is very light, and very easy to install. It just needs to be run under the water for a few moments to reach an ideal temperature and prevent it from fogging up. I usually let it sit on the floor of the shower to have the water run over it while I handle my pre-shave business in the shower.<br /><br />If shaving takes long [like it does for me] you may have to run it under water more than once because it'll start to fog eventually, but this is a non-issue to me, and it still makes this product superior to more expensive shaving mirrors.

  532. I have the worst luck with shower mirrors. They break, they fog up, and they always get scratched and unusable eventually.<br /><br />I like this one, though. It is not actually &#34;fogless&#34;, but de-fogging it is very easy. It hangs on a small hook, and is easily removed to run under the water. De-fogging the mirror is simply a matter of equalizing the temperature of the mirror to the air around it, and running this under the water stream for a few seconds accomplishes this fairly well.<br /><br />Also, they recommend cleaning with toothpaste and your fingers so that it doesn't scratch. This works well, too, and only takes a very tiny amount of toothpaste.<br /><br />I wish it were a little bigger, but it is light, compact, and such a refreshingly simple design after all the over-designed, lighted behemoths I'm used to breaking. Get one, if you need a mirror in the shower for shaving, etc. I think you'll be fairly happy with it.

  534. This is a mirror to hang in your shower and it doesn't get any more complex than that.   559. To keep this fog free you hold it under the water for about a minute. Warmed up, it does not fog for several minutes. When it does begin to fog, just put it back under the water again.<br /><br />All these mirrors work under one of two principles. They either have a fog free coating or they the heat up. A mirror that is as warm as the water won't fog up. The ones with the coating, a type of wax, must have it reapplied from time to time. They often provide a few samples of the wax then try to sell you more.<br /><br />This works as advertised. The problem I had was you need a very bright room. I have two large, frosted windows in my bathroom and when the sun is out they provide plenty of light to see, but not enough to see in the mirror.<br /><br />I have a large bathroom and even if I turn on all the lights, I cannot see very well in the mirror. I had to throw it away.<br /><br />I would not buy this unless you have a very bright bathroom.

  574. This is a great little mirror. easy to install and so convenient with no worry of dropping and breaking. It cleans easily with a little tooth paste and is truly fog free. Highly recommend
  575. I have yet to find a truly fog free mirror. The product packaging says to hold mirror in shower stream on both sides of mirror to prevent it from fogging up. The best this does is give you a few extra seconds of fog free experience. This product's true advantage over the competition (in my opinion) is that it does not attach with a suction cup. All my other fog free mirrors would eventually fall off the shower wall and break because the suction cup would innevitably let loose at some point. Instead, this product comes with a peel-n-stick hook that attaches to your shower wall. While some might see this as a negative, I have not been awoken at 3 am by a loud &#34;thud&#34; trying to figure out what just happened since using this mirror. Because it is completely flat, it is very easy to take on your travels. A cheap suction cup hook thrown in with your luggage allows you to hang it up in your hotel shower.
  576. It's perfect. No fogging, easily held with a hole to slide your finger through, and nothing extra, just a mirror with a textured backing. This mirror is solid. I suggest warming mirror up with the hot water then wipe the front with a dry rag. This will give you a clear view for shaving in the shower. Keep the back of the mirror warm by running hot water over the back if it starts to fog.<br />I have used 15 different mirrors that the women in my life have. None come close to this mirror. The $15 is money well spent because it took me 3 minutes less to shave. That's 12 hours a year! Plus the savings on water. BUY THE MIRROR and enjoy your free time.
  577. I've tried almost every fog free mirror there is out there for shaving in the shower and this by far is the best. Run it under warm water from your shower and you will experience a fog free shave every day. Mine's going on year two, which is the longest I've ever had a fog free mirror that I didn't wind up needing to squint into every morning as they normally develop a permanent &#34;fog&#34; on them.

  607. For those of us males who blade shave, shaving in the shower is the holy grail, as the wetter and softer the beard the better. I'd tried two different no-fog treatments for our vanity mirror, Rain-ex liquid and a paste called Brite Sight that came in a yellow tub and was sold many years ago at fairs and flea markets, I still had a 20+ yr old tub laying around and said \\"what the hell\\". Results were both the same. They both did merely \\"OK\\" on fog but failed after one treatment. So I decided to part with 10 bucks and try this mirror. I was initially a bit concerned as to whether the hanger adhesive would stick to our uneven ceramic tiles but I just picked a flat(er) section and it stuck, no problem. As to performance, it works exactly as advertised. When you're ready to shave, hold it under the hot shower for a few seconds and you have a fog free mirror for the duration. I shave with a 50 yr old Gillette double edged adjustable (best razor ever made IMO) so there's the whole shaving bowl, (or mug) badger brush and razor juggle to deal with, but the palm sized, light weight mirror was a breeze to get used to. As to the size issue a few others have complained about. I don't get it. The description states that it's 4\\"x6\\" no surprises. The mirror is slightly convex (like the passenger side mirror on your car) and I can see my whole face from about 18\\" away and I've got a pretty big head. So all in all, it works great, it only costs $10. Inexpensive solution to a difficult problem. What's not to like?

  651. I got this mirror to finally be able to shave in the shower to help eliminate irritation and have a better shaving experience.   653. When I first pulled the mirror out the box, I was surprised to find the mirror smaller than I anticipated. After using it, I discovered the size to be perfect. After a few weeks the hook fell off the tile wall in the shower. I added a stronger adhesive to the hook and reapplied it to wall. No problem since.
