  658. I've owned one of these for 2.5 years. I've used both the regular and the deluxe size of this mirror. The deluxe size is definitely nicer in terms of seeing my whole big face in there, but for just normal face shaving, the regular (smaller) one works fine. I own the normal one, and use it daily. I've bought deluxe ones for my father and my brother, and use them when I visit (self serving gifts for the win!). If I were to recommend one, I'd definitely recommend the deluxe, but I still just own and use the regular.<br /><br />Really, the mirror is great. It's pretty simple.. A piece of acrylic, with the mirror surface on the back side of the acrylic (which makes it sensitive to scratching.. see below). Not much to it. If you have a drafty shower, it will fog up significantly faster.. Also, I use a cheap suction cup + plastic hook that I picked up at Target, rather than the included hook (which uses some double-sided foam tape). Mostly because I was going to be traveling with the thing and moving it around.<br /><br />I've dropped the mirror in a tile shower from 5+ feet DOZENS of times, and it's still in one piece. It makes a heck of a noise, but it has never broken, chipped, etc. It's acrylic, it's pretty tough.<br /><br />The only thing to note with the mirror, is that it can scratch if you don't treat it carefully. If you push it around on hard surfaces, it will totally scratch. It's nothing to really be surpised about, but just be aware, if you happen to throw it lazily into a travel bag, etc. Since the back (reflective mirror material) side isn't protected, you could wind up with scratches in the mirror image. Mine got a few scratches from me treating it like it was indestructible, so I now treat it much nicer. Just saying. The simplicity and the &#34;fogless&#34; feature has the drawback of the unprotected surfaces, so just be careful with it. If you put it in your shower, and never move it, it will not scratch. You literally need to be putting it on hard surfaces, etc, or where it can rub against hard stuff. I move mine around between showers, traveling, etc, so it has seen more mileage than most, I'm sure. Again, I've owned one for 2.5 years, and in that time, it picked up 2 scratches in the actual mirror material (shows up at thin black lines when looking in the mirror), and a few scratches on the front.<br /><br />Yes, it will collect water droplets, when you rinse it / warm it up. If you are so inclined, you could wax the surface with car wax, or something..? No idea how that would hold up in the long run.. I surely didn't do that! For me, if there are way too many water droplets, I put it into the shower stream again, and try for a less obvious pattern. I really don't notice the droplets after a moment, though. I also have hard water, and the mirror hasn't had any problems with water marks, and I've never needed to or attempted to clean it.. Maybe the near-daily rinse keeps it fresh.
  659. Excellent product! Really clear and for a guy like me that only has vision in one eye, this is excellent. Great price as well.
  660. Very convenient mirror. It is small but nice it doesnt take up a lot of space. Sticks right in our shower door and has not fallen off in many many months. Just hold it under the shower water for a quick second and it will stay fog free and clear. Hubby is happy with this for a quick shave in the shower.
  661. Works pretty good, have been using it for months without an issue.
  662. I've been shaving in a shower for over 40 years. In that time, I've purchased at least one shaving mirror a year, with space age coatings, transistor radios, lights, ones that hooked into the plumbing, ones \\"guaranteed to never fog\\" and they are all, in the immortal words of Animal House \\"worthless and weak\\". For the last several months, I've been shaving blind, which is one of my worst ideas ever.<br />These guys, however, have solved the Rubik's Cube. I've only had this for less than a week, but it does exactly what it says it will do. Running the shower water over the \\"mirror\\" creates a shiny reflective surface that is bright and clear. I find the size perfect for holding in my hand while I shave, but I'm liking hanging it back on the wall-it is remarkably bright and easy to use.<br />I'll be curious to see how it holds up, but if you're in the market, don't waste your money on these other products. They're all spiffy for a few months, then they give up the ghost and quit working.<br />The Shave Well is just that.<br />One thing I'm not sold on is the sticky hook deal.. My shower is quarry stone, so I've had a screw mount for years. Works fine for this mirror. I am skeptical that the hook will actually stick for the long run to a shower wall, but with fiberglass being sort of the standard shower wall, probably not much choice.
  663. I have been shaving in the shower for 20 years. I've had a few mirrors, some better than others, but none great. This one is great. The fact that its temperature matches that of the shower in seconds, and therefore prevents condensation, is brilliant. The only downside is that my hook didn't stay attached to the wall. Not sure if I didn't give it enough time, or the adhesive didn't like my tile. Now I rest it on a ledge which is the perfect height for me. One tip: if you squeegee the mirror after it's been sprayed, it becomes crystal clear. I have a glass door on my shower which I squeegee after every shower, so I had one already.
  664. Well, it kinda works. But not all that great. and Definitely not how they say it does.<br /><br />Now I have a beard. And it's ALL THEIR FAULT.
  665. I've had this product for about eight months. While its defogging ability is OK, holding it under the water to warm it up does leave many water droplets that distort the view; shaking it just breaks these up into tinier drops, which is worse--but this is no better or worse than other fogless mirrors I've had. The bigger problem, however, is that the stick-on hook eventually fails. After applying it according to the directions, the hook was fine until about two weeks ago, when it fell off the tile wall--now no amount of coaxing will keep it stuck on. Holding it in one hand while you shave is a pain. A reasonable short-term solution, but that's about it.<br /><br />Update: Shave Well contacted me immediately after this review was posted and offered to send a new hook--thanks! They did seem to think, however, that eight months was a long period of time for the hook adhesive to last. For comparison, I had my last fogless shaving mirror for over twenty years--through two moves (for which the manufacturer supplied additional adhesive strips)--and it NEVER came off the wall. The last move was sixteen years ago, and the manfacturer seems to have gone out of business--probably because their product lasted too long. I had to replace it because the fogless feature finally deteriorated to the point of uselessness.<br /><br />Another Update: Shave Well did indeed live up to their promise, and sent both an adhesive and a suction hook. Thanks, Shave Well!
  666. Its OK, not what I was expecting but not their fault. Works fairly well, though. If is gets foggy just hit it with the hot shower water and you are good to again.   669. I purchased this mirror because of the great reviews and because I of course needed a shaving mirror for the shower that wouldn't fog up. I have tried many \\"fogless\\" shave mirrors and still have not found one that lives up to it's claims. Pros: -Easy installation (You just stick the hook on the wall, and that's it.) -Lightweight/Durable (I feel like if I dropped this while in the shower, it wouldn't get damaged like some other shave mirrors.) -Would work with any sticky backed mounting hook if anything were to happen to the original. Cons: -It fogs up! I followed the instructions and held the mirror under the hot shower for about 30 seconds on each side, hung it up, and started to shave. About 1/2 my face in to the shave it started fogging up on one side, then by the time I was on my upper lip it was totally fogged over. I had to stop, re-warm the mirror and put it back up.. and I'm a fairly quick shaver. -Small (Like really small, the picture doesn't convey how small this thing is.) Conclusion: I think because of all the stellar reviews I had my expectations set too high. I should have known that there is no miracle mirror that doesn't fog up. I will stick with this mirror just because of the simple mounting and the fact that I'm pretty sure it will never fall off the wall. I have modified my review to 5 stars. UPDATE 1/7/2015: Well it's been about 2.5 years and I've used this shaving mirror every day since I got it. I figured out that if I hold it under the water for about a minute, the mirror won't fog up during use. I also got a new shower curtain that doesn't let in as much cold air.
  670. I was pretty disappointed by this product. I've used the Zadro ZM01 happily for years (though you have to replace them pretty often). But I saw the reviews for this and thought I'd try something new. The size is ok, and I like the hook mount better than the Zadro suction cups (though I haven't had this up for very long, so I don't know how the hook will perform over the long haul in the shower). And following the instructions, the mirror does indeed not FOG, as advertised. However, the surface of the mirror also does not shed water, and so the mirror is constantly covered in tiny water droplets, both left over from \\"heating\\" it under the hot water (as the instructions require) and from just being in the shower. So while there is no condensation or fog on the mirror, the actual water on the mirror makes it of little use. The reflection is not clear and unobstructed. Very frustrating. The Zadro ZM01 mirror has some kind of coating on it that the water sheds off of it leaving the surface clear and unobstructed, for a far better shaving reflection. The coating on the Zadro breaks down pretty quickly, and the surface gets scuffed easily, so I find myself replacing the Zadro a couple of times a year. I thought this mirror might change all that. But I'll be heading back to the Zadro. I'd rather have a mirror that works well out of the box, even if it has a limited life span.

  684. I've been using this mirror for a little over 3 months now. It works as advertised - I just hold it under the warm water for several seconds and it remains fog-free throughout my shave. There is now just under 1/8th of an inch of the gray coating on the back that has flaked off from the bottom edge on back. If it continues at this rate, it'll be 1/4&#34; in another 3 months and 1/2&#34; after a year at which point it will have surpassed being an eyesore and will continue to reduce the usable area. My suggestion to the manufacturer is to apply an additional hard coating on the back AND OVER THE EDGES to increase durability. Even if this adds a dollar to the selling price, it would be well worth it to avoid having to buy another one every year or two. Then again, maybe that's what they WANT you to do! &#34;Planned obsolescence.&#34; UPDATE 2/6/15: Following my original complaint about the gray coating on back peeling off, I was sent a replacement mirror at no charge by The Shave Well Company. The coating on the original mirror only peeled about 3/16&#34; before stopping. It hasn't peeled any more. I couldn't ask for better customer service and I'm completely satisfied with this mirror. I'm now changing my rating from 3 stars to 5 stars. UPDATE 2/9/17: It's now been over 4-1/2 years and I'm still using the original mirror. A little more of the gray coating peeled off, but it's still perfectly usable.

  721. This is how it works for me: 1. Initially the mirror fogs up, 2. then one warms up the mirror with water, and 3. the mirror stays fog-free for about 10 minutes until it has cooled down enough, 4. when the procedure starts all over again. So, the mirror works somewhat, but when I read \\"TRULY FOG FREE\\", then I expect a mirror that never fogs up. It comes down to a \\"SOMEWHAT FOG FREE\\" mirror. The description explains the simple thermodynamic physic law this mirror is benefiting from, so there is really nothing particular novel about this mirror. But that is actually the good about this mirror: a simple, handy, and lasting design that works. 4 stars for a simple and functional mirror and good customer support. 5 if it were not \\"over-advertised\\" and the word \\"truly\\" were removed.
  722. Great shaving mirror but small for using in the shower. Could be 50% bigger The fog free feature works well!!
  723. I've shaved in the shower for about two decades, and have gone through countless mirrors. The only one's I have not tried are the direct-attach water mirrors, but those are basically high priced gimmicks that take the place of an easily removable mirror such as this. I must say, I've gone thru about 15 or so mirrors in my shower-shaving life, and each one was pretty much a \\"stick-on and leave\\"; that is, once they are attached to your shower wall, it is either impossible to remove in some cases, or difficult to reattach in others (suction cup type, where the suction cup needs the wall to be clean and DRY to re-attach). In all these cases, cleaning had to be remembered, not something done in the shower WHILE you are showering, which is when most of us actually remember to clean our shower mirrors. This mirror though, seems to be different. First off, it does not attach to your shower wall via sticky strip or suction cup...it hangs from the included sticky-strip hook. This is better off than all the others in ease of cleaning as well as ease of use. 2nd, by removing it from the hang hook, you can use it for normally hard to view areas of your face that you used to twist and turn to see. Nice. My only complaint, which is the only reason I awarded it 4 out of 5 stars, is it's size. It is about 4x6. They claim this is helpful in holding it in your hand while shaving, but honestly a 8x11 size is just as easy. It's not like these things are heavy; they weigh a couple ounces. Making it bigger won't add but a couple more ounces, and my razor weighs more than that. This would eliminate the need to remove it to see all your face; as it is, you can only see about 3/4 of your face, and I like to see all of it. Regardless of that single flaw, I believe it is better than every mirror I have used so far.
  724. This is an update to my previous review below... After talking to them on the phone, I realized I was trying the remove the protective coating on the wrong side of the mirror.   727. On the product:<br /><br />This really is a great product--when you run the mirror under hot water and hang it, it really does stay fogless so long as you keep the hot water running.   728. I've been using this for about a year now, must say great investment. Does works as advertised, I like to shave in the shower sometimes and very cheap price this does its job. When I run the mirror under the water front and back then it doesn't fog up.
  729. I followed the instructions to the letter (the ones included with the produce and the ones emailed to me by the seller), but their fog free solution did not work for me. The say all you need to do is hold the mirror in the shower stream to equalize the temperature of the mirror with the air temperature in the shower. When I did this, I ended up with a mirror covered with water droplets (too many to see through) that fogged back up in about one minute. My solution was to spray the mirror with some shower cleaner (Clorox Clean-up) just before I wanted to use it. This resulted in a droplet free, fog free mirror. The other problem I've had is with the mirror staying attached to the wall. The mirror itself has a hole in the top that hooks onto a plastic hook that attached to the wall of the shower with self-adhesive tape. Again, I followed the product's (and seller's) instructions exactly when attaching the hook and the mirror seems to weigh practically nothing. BUT, the hook (and mirror) fell to the floor of the shower after just two weeks. So, to summarize, to make the mirror fog free, spray it with something like Clorox Clean-up before every use and don't leave the mirror hanging on the hook unless you are using the mirror.
  730. Bought this for my husband. He is happy with it. I wouldnt say this is truly fog free though. But works well.
  731. I would buy &#34;fog free&#34;, or maybe even &#34;truly fog free&#34; or &#34;FOG FREE&#34;, but &#34;TRULY FOG FREE&#34; it is not. It's pretty good, but will fog up over time as I'm guessing anything will. Better than an average mirror though.
  732. This is a good product and for the price, just about everything I could ask for. If you follow the instructions, you should have no major problems shaving in the shower.   734. After putting it under warm water it is fog free, only for a couple of minutes. But who really needs more than that to shave?<br /><br />Also, the design of this mirror could be a little better. After putting the mirror back on the hook after heating it up, there are always a couple of water droplets that slide down the middle of the mirror. However after experimenting I noticed that after heating it up and then putting it sideways (or in a landscape orientation) there aren't any droplets of water going down the mirror. Just something to think about
  735. Wonderfully simple, installs in seconds. This shower mirror is the simplest and perhaps the best yet.   744. PRO:<br />This mirror's hook stays on the wall.<br />It does not fog up if warmed in the shower water.<br />It is not too small, just the right size.<br /><br />CON:<br />BUT I don't use it. Before you buy this you should consider whether your shower is well lit enough for it to be of use, although it does not fog, it will be covered with water drops and if you get up close to it, your breath will temporarily fog it. When combined with poor lighting, it doesn't really give that good a view of your shave. Also, while you stand there in the shower shaving for several minutes, you will want the water to be on so you won't freeze to death. I decided to do my shaving at the bathroom mirror, after my shower, to save water and my eyesight.

  765. I have been using this fog free shower shave mirror for about a week and it works just as advertised. If you hold the mirror under warm shower water for fifteen or twenty seconds on both sides, the mirror remains fog free for the duration of the shower. I am writing this review for another reason. The device comes with a protective film over the mirror which is almost impossible to remove. It is clearly a design flaw and a mistake. I patiently took a quarter and rubbed it over the top of the mirror to remove the protective film and only after much patience did I finally get a sliver of opening to remove the film, which then came off quite easily. The makers of this mirror should include a tab at the top of the mirror to remove the protective film. Those who buy this mirror, don't despair, the film fill come off with some patience on your part.

  786. I bought it for my husband and he love it. He said that it really doesn't fog
  787. This mirror works great if you read the instructions! I don't understand how you couldn't, yet still many 1-2 star reviews. The box, the insert, the instructions and ALL over these Amazon reviews....RUN IT UNDER THE WATER TO MAKE THE MIRROR THE SAME TEMP AS THE SHOWER!!<br />Goodness sake, condensation is not some magical work of the devil, it's when WARM HUMID air collects on a COLD surface. Bring the cold surface up to the same temperature and TA DA no condensation. There is no special coating, no magic, nothing.<br />So what makes this little guy special?<br /><br />1. Size. Not to big not to small. Light enough to hang from a hook without coming off the wall. Pack in a travel bag. Take camping. Etc<br /><br />2. Its plastic and light. The worry of glass in the shower is eliminated and with the added rounded corners, I don't think it would be a big deal if you dropped it. I don't know because I never have. I hold it in my wet hand all the time to get the right angle or better light (another plus for is smaller size!)<br /><br />3. Price. Around $10 & The Shave Well Company has very good customer service based on what I've seen in reviews and comment responses.<br /><br />One tip that really makes this mirror work is after you rinse/heat it up 'squeegee' it with the edge of some bar soap one time, this will put a thin layer of soap you can see through but will prevent water from beading up on it...
  788. I bought this for my husband. He never uses it. He said it fogs up.

  791. Just got mine and used it twice - very reasonably priced, works as advertised, is VERY light so secures to shower wall easily. YOu can make it perform even better using a little trick i learned that makes most mirrors fogfree ... just wipe some shampoo lather on the mirror and let it run off while you are showering - by the time you are ready to shave the soap will have mostly all run off and left behind a clear mirror - may have somethign to do it a thin soap film preventing fog from forming ... anyway it always works for me. And no need to hold the mirror under the water. The key for me is that this mirror is so light - most mirror eventually fall and break. Enjoy.

  802. While I have purchased dozens of products through Amazon, this mirror has compelled me to write my first product review. In my experience it is a very poor product. I have been shaving in the shower for over thirty years and have always used a small glass make-up type mirror. A regular mirror would last me years before the coating would finally wear down enough to partially block the reflection. Based on the positive reviews here, I decided to give the Shave Well Fog Free Mirror a try. My first impression was that the mirror is nothing more than a cheap piece of coated Plexiglas, not much bigger than an I-phone. But, again based on the reviews, I decided to withhold judgment until I actually used the mirror for a while. The hanging hook went on well, and the mirror was ready to go.<br /> Using the mirror as instructed, it seemed to work moderately well although the water droplets left on the mirror after running it under the shower seemed to distort the reflection more than on a glass mirror I was used to using. While not completely happy with the operation of the mirror, I nonetheless decided to continue using it as I had already paid for it.<br />After just a couple of weeks, I noticed that the gray \\"paint\\" on the reverse side of the mirror had started flaking off. While at first it didn't seem to affect the mirror coating, it was still disturbing to me. Then, a short time later, the actual mirror coating began to flake off. It is not a huge area yet but I suspect it will just continue to get worse.<br /> Pretty poor workmanship considering the relatively high cost of this product.<br />Perhaps I received one from a \\"bad batch\\" as reported by an earlier reviewer. If that is the case, I will hope to hear from the manufacturer about a replacement.

  805. I used to shave in the shower by using a typical handheld mirror flipped upside down and placed carefully on a wall mounted razor holder. This meant I had to constantly worry about the suction cup failing, thus sending the glass mirror to its untimely death and shattering all over the place. I like the fact that this one won't shatter or break, because I always had a fear of seeing the mirror fall, trying to catch it, and slashing myself with the razor as I make the split second action. As far as the anti-fogging capability, it seems to work pretty well. I take fairly hot showers and would venture to guess the initial heat up lasts for 80% of my shave. I hold it under the hot water for about 20-30 seconds total, flipping it over every few seconds. From there, as I see it start to fog slightly I'll just get a mouthful of water as I'm rinsing my face and splash it on the mirror again. Not much trouble at all to do so and it seems to help it keep up its temperature. With all that said, mine appears to have some sort of defect where it looks like the backing is flaking off around the edges. I can't tell what's going on because nothing on the front or back is damaged, it's almost like it's happening from within the mirror. You can see what I mean by checking this picture out: [...] That's happening all over the bottom and around the mounting hole as well. It doesn't affect me when I shave, it's just annoying to see and appears to be getting slowly worse. As such, I give it a 4/5.
  806. This mirror does exactly what the name says it will do. I have gone through many cheap \\"fog free\\" mirrors that are unusable after a few weeks. I am rarely inspired to write product reviews but I wish I had come across this product sooner and saved some dough.

  819. Love the customer support, the clear instructions, the fact that it's removable, and the fact that it works!<br /><br />Very happy with my purchase; but I find the mirror to be quite small, which is why I deducted one star.
  820. If you have ever NOT shaved because it is a pain to get out all your gear and clean up afterwards, you should be shaving in the shower. This product is all you need to do so.<br /><br />This mirror is fog-free, as advertised, and is lightweight, so I'm not worried about dropping it on my foot or having it fall on someone taking a bath (wife or kid). The included hook attaches easily and has more than enough strength to hold it up. I even flip it up on the hook (mirror hole on bottom side) and lean it forward to get a downward angle on the mirror, which is nice. Best of all, the price is right, so you don't have to invest an arm and a leg if shower shaving isn't for you.<br /><br />Advice: Position the mirror at a comfortable height opposite of your shower head so that you avoid spraying water on the mirror while you are shaving. I placed mine a bit too close and have to wipe it off a couple times during shaving. With your back to the shower head, this probably wouldn't be an issue.<br /><br />As many others have mentioned, the company behind this product is very responsive and believe in their product. If you don't like the product, I'm sure they'd be happy to refund or replace.
  821. I was skeptical about this thing actually working in the shower, but all you have to do is run it under the water for a few seconds and it's good to go.
  822. I've had lots of shaving mirrors for the shower. This is the only one that works!!. And was less expensive than any other!!!
  823. The mirror works as it says it does. The only thing i would do different is make it a bit bigger. There are suction ones that aren't that well created but are large. If it this one was it would absolutely be 5star worthy.
  824. I had a problem with the hook included with this product, and the vice president of the company took notice that I was unsatisfied and personally rectified the matter at no cost to me. You won't get this level of dedication from Wal-Mart! Thanks guys. Mirror works great now.
  825. This product works exactly how it says it will. The grib does work well. My husband loves it, and now he can shave in the shower instead of getting facial hair all in my sink and on my bathroom counter. Thumbs up.
  826. Be sure to read all the instructions carefully before deciding on the place for the hook. It must not be anywhere near the shower curtain or in the path of air that circulates around the curtain. Also, be sure to follow the guidelines about how high the mirror must hang.
  827. Shaving in the shower definitely makes for a smoother and closer shave. The trade-off is that you may be wasting a fair amount of water while doing so. On the other hand, turning off the water flow while shaving can make for a rather cold experience and negate the comfort benefit of a smooth and close shave. By installing a shower fixture with separate temperature and volume controls I've been able to minimize that drawback, since I can reduce water flow to a minimum while maintaining the proper temperature. Having done so, I can speak to the effectiveness of this mirror in a guilt-free manner. If only solving other ecological trade-offs - like choosing between paper and plastic when you forget to bring your own shopping bag - was so easy...<br /><br />Pro's:<br />Safe in case you drop the it - Acrylic will not shatter, so no worries about a potential undesirable situation of glass shards on the shower floor.<br /><br />Hook adheres well - Should you need to remove it in the future, any minor adhesive residue appears to be easily cleaned off without harsh chemicals.<br /><br />Truly fog-free - At least in my small shower stall, the air temperature stays warm enough for a fog-free experience once you have warmed the mirror as per the directions. Also, it is easy to re-warm the mirror if a cooler air-stream hits it while shaving.<br /><br />Customer communication and service is superb; I received an informative email even before delivery of the mirror, and printed information accompanying the mirror is clear and well-designed. Unlike most companies, the ShaveWell Company really means it when they say that customer delight with their product is the most important thing. Take a look at what other reviewers have to say about their prompt and helpful responses to customer questions.<br /><br />Con's (Minor):<br />The mirror is fairly small - Depending on how your shower/bath stall configuration impacts where you hang it (and your eyesight), you might need to stand out ofthe shower flow in order to use it while it is hanging. If so, that can make for a chilly experience. My preference is to hang it far enough from the main water flow to minimize soapy spray that would lead to residue build-up, and in my small shower stall I can do so yet remain in a warm water flow.<br /><br />Water remains beaded up on the mirror after warming it - Shaving visibilty remains OK, but it would be nice if the mirror was coated with a product that enables water to run-off such as those used on auto windshields and glass shower/bath doors.<br /><br />Easily scratchable - Acrylic is clearly the safe choice for an in-shower mirror, but you need to exercise care when cleaning it. Should some soap scum eventually build up, be sure to use the proper cleaning agent and a soft cloth.<br /><br />Overall Assessment:<br />An inexpensive product that does what it promises from a company that truly cares about its customers. Big quality of life boost if you can minimize water waste / guilt. I would give it 5 stars if it came in a slightly larger size with a coating that enables water beads to run off.<br /><br />Update: SIMPLE TOOTHPASTE METHOD FOR REDUCING WATER BEADING - I tried the toothpaste suggestion for treating the mirror emailed to me from the Shave Well Company immediately after posting my review (and originally suggested by another reviewer) and found that it works quite well for minimizing water beading on the mirror during use. Simply wet the mirror, gently rub it with a pea-sized bit of toothpaste, rinse off, and repeat as needed. An additional benefit is that it delays soap scum build-up. I would suggest using a plain, inexpensive toothpaste instead of the fancy \\"whitening\\" toothpastes, which often contain fine polishing granules that might scratch the acrylic mirror.
  828. This little mirror is excellent. It's built tough and the mirror is well protected from the elements it will encounter in the shower. It is simple, which is perfect because you don't want any nooks or crannies to trap water. It has a large hole at the top that enables you to hang it anywhere you want, and it comes with a stick on plastic hook. So far I am very pleased with this mirror. It's a really great design.

  840. Like many others, I thought there was something special about this mirror that helped it not to fog. It's called water! In the instructions, it tells you to hold it under the warm water for about a minute to equalize the temperature between the mirror and the environment. YOU CAN DO THAT TO ANY MIRROR! I gave it four stars because it does, in fact, do exactly what is advertised. However, I don't need any special mirror to accomplish the same thing.<br />Get a mirror at Walmart and run some water over it until it's warm. That's all you need to do. And you have the added benefit of getting a mirror that is aesthetically pleasing, rather than a piece of mirror that looks like it was cut from an assembly line.
  841. i bought this for my sons' shower. they followed the directions and put it at the end on the wall, it works great for them. i would recommend this. we also got a letter from the manufacturer in the mail reiterating the directions and making sure we knew about the warranty - impressive.
  842. It is a simple, almost elegant solution for us shower shavers. I have been a shower shaver for years and along the way have tried a variety of products. But I grew tried of adding hot water to chambers or rubbing special towelettes on the surface. This mirror works on simple physics; warm it under the shower stream and it will say clear and give you a nice shave. After five minutes or so, if it starts to fog a bit just repeat the process. The only change I made was in the method of cleaning; instead of toothpaste, I have found that 409 cleaner works best for me, keeps spots away and drops from clinging for about a week at a time. After a few weeks, I purchased the travel version, too and it works just as well. Happy shaving.

  851. I don't usually write reviews on Amazon, but I felt I had no choice in this matter. I gave this product 5 stars and I'll explain why. After reading reviews for other fog resistant mirrors, I was weary about buying ANY of them. Nobody seemed happy with the purchase and it sounded like the whole idea of a fog resistant shower mirror was too good to be true, like nobody had really nailed the idea yet. Well, these guys have. The thing that sets this mirror apart from others that I looked at are two things; one, the hanging method is secure and stable, but designed so that the mirror can be easily lifted off at any time, which is important because two, it needs to be removable to truly achieve a fog free surface. The company uses a simple explanation of how the mirror does this using basic science. Basically you just have to lift the mirror off and let the shower water hit both sides for a few seconds. When you do, the mirror's surface temperature rises to match the room temperature and condensation will no longer stick to the surface. It sounds weird, but it works EXTREMELY well and the mirror stays fog free more than enough time to complete a shave. Also of note, the mirror SEEMS small when you first see it, like it would be too small to shave comfortably, but once you use it, you will find it that the size is actually perfect.<br /><br />But all that aside, the reason I REALLY wanted to write this review is because of the awesome customer service. When I attached the hanging hook to my bathroom wall, I foolishly hung it too low. I know, stupid mistake. But I could still use it by just leaning over, so I decided to live with it because I didn't feel like screwing up the adhesive on the back of the hook. A day later, I got an email from the company's Executive Vice President, asking if I was satisfied with the product and if he could answer any questions for me. I would have just left it alone, but since he emailed me, I decided to reply and ask if there was any way totake the hook off and reapply it without screwing up the adhesive. He confirmed that once the hook is removed, the adhesive is ruined and won't stick again. But then, he asked my for mailing address and said he would ship me a new hook - completely free. A few days later, the new hook showed up in my mailbox. So basically, I screwed up the product myself, and the Vice President went out of his way to check on my product, and then offered to fix MY screw-up at his own expense.<br /><br />Folks, you just don't find customer service like that anymore. Not only is the product solid but the company is fantastic, and I have no reservations about recommending this to everybody.

  895. This mirror works. It does get foggy, but it does so far less readily or often as other mirrors that claim to be fog free.<br /><br />A little piece of advice?<br /><br />Do not place the hook in such a way that the mirror is going to be flat against the wall and stuck to it because it gets wet.<br />Instead, place it so that it hangs a quarter inch away from the wall.<br />It's now gonna fog less!<br />But, now, it's gonna shake and sing, because you breath swings it.<br />So, place a couple of those rubber round half-ball glue-on feet on the wall.<br />They will provide support so that it doesn't swing around.<br />(Another lesson here is that you should try to breathe away from the mirror, as your breath is far hotter than the shower mist (no pun intended).)<br /><br />As a complete solution, it sucks. But, hey, we live in an imperfect world.<br />And this mirror gets to being as fog free as this imperfect world allows.<br /><br />Impeccable packaging and shipment.

  906. Works just as advertised. I didn't like the hook it came with because it is basically permanent so I got a section cup hook and since the mirror isn't heavy it works great. If I had to purchase again, I would probably get the larger one.
  907. I wasn't expecting much at the price. Something that was functional enough but not that great. This is a travel sized mirror that actually works as a full size mirror replacement. Packs well. Works well. Just make sure before you buy that you pruchase the mount appropriate to the environment where you plan to use it. The hole for the hook is a pretty good size, though, so you can get away with using other hooks you have around. The mirror it quite light so command hooks or really just about anything that can hold over a few ounces will do fine. I haven't been particularly rough with it, but it seems like it would be fine for camping or a business trip.
  908. Does exactly what it claims to do, no more, no less. Perfect for shaving in the shower, a quick rinse under the water if it is at all foggy and it's good to go.

  918. 1st-The \\"Will Not fall off the wall\\" statement is not exactly true. Now the problem is, that hook will not stay stuck on any/all tiles.I have the little glass squares (approx. 1\\" X 1\\") and it will not adhere to them.<br /><br />2nd-Not an issue, but the mirror is small, (think of those magnet locker mirrors people used to have in school)<br /><br />3rd-The manufacturers guarantee \\"No Fog\\" as its pure science that as long as you put the mirror front and back under water that is the same temp as the steam the shower is currently producing you will have a \\"fog free\\" experience. I have a steam unit for my shower, the temp gets to over 110 degrees so it is difficult for me to have the results claimed or in this case, desired.<br /><br />Overall, buy this if you are sure the hook will adhere, you do not have steam for your shower

  937. This is a plastic mirror with a plastic hook. There's nothing &#34;UNIQUE&#34; or clever about this mirror, other than the marketing and hype. It should be considered false advertising, in fact. &#34;Truly fogless by design&#34; is a false statement. There is nothing fogless about the mirror itself. You HAVE to run it under the warm water, and even then it quickly fogs up in about 30 seconds. Due to its plastic design, the water beads up nicely on the front of this mirror, which impairs your vision to boot.<br /><br />What you have here is a plastic mirror worth about $0.55, a plastic hook with adhesive worth about $0.15, a thin protection sheet worth about $0.05, and a colorful printed box and instructions worth about $0.25 (all in bulk). The marketing team behind this mirror spends at least twice that amount per mirror in advertising and hype.<br /><br />Here's a little clue - ANY mirror is &#34;fog free&#34; if you run it under the shower water to warm it up. I find it very hard to believe there are that many people happy paying $10 for something you could find at a dollar store that works just as well. Heck, you could even use the broken shard of a truck stop mirror stuck to your shower wall with the piece of gum you found on the bathroom stall and it would be exactly as &#34;fog free by design&#34; as this mirror. Just pull it off the gum, run it under the warm water, then stick it back on the gummy adhesive. Bam! Fog Free mirror! (I'm certain the US patent office would even grant you a patent for that &#34;unique&#34; truck stop design and feel.)<br /><br />Do yourself a favor; spend the $10 towards a removable shower head and keep the mirror you already have. Then you can bring the shower head to the mirror to warm it up and make it &#34;fog free&#34; instead of lining the pockets of these false advertising scammers.<br /><br />One star for the ability to remove it from the hook to clean all the fog and beaded water off the mirror when I'm done showering.

  953. If it wasn't clear from the description, this mirror is a small piece of mirrored plastic (plexiglass) with a thumbhole in it, and an adhesive hook.<br /><br />I sure liked the idea of a mirror with no metal to rust, as that seems to be the downfall of all of them.<br /><br />However, there are two key problems with this mirror.. first, because it hangs from the peg, it tends to be pointing a different direction every time. You have to dance a little to get into view. It doesn't help that the mirror is really pretty small. You might end up just holding it in one hand, rather than letting it dangle at odd angles.<br /><br />Second, you have to run it under the water to warm up and stop fogging. That's the plan. The problem then is that you have beaded drops of water all over the mirror. You have to wipe it or clean it off to use. Even wiped, it is distorted and hard to see well over the wet mirror.<br /><br />All in all, not a keeper.
  954. I bought this mirror for a different reason than most: to help my 5 year-old learn how to properly shampoo his hair! He was missing spots and couldn't quite \\"feel\\" them, so I researched a lot of other shower mirrors before finally deciding on this one. It stays fog free when my son remembers to warm it up and it does get some water beading on it during the shower (we have it hung at his eye level at the far end of a tub/shower combo), but it has helped him be able to see and he has become a better hair washer (and incidentally also a better goofy face maker) thanks to the mirror. I also need to say that it is durable! Being a 5 year-old, you can imagine how many times it has been dropped and it shows zero sign of damage!   959. The mirror works as advertised. Simply run it under the hot water for a little bit and it stays fogless easily long enough to shave. Note how it works: the mirror must be at a temperature higher than the air temperature. If it's fogging up quickly it's because the mirror dropped below the air temperature. Possibly it's too high, above the shower curtain, and catching a breeze from outside the shower or maybe you need to keep under the warm water longer.<br /><br />For me, the mirror works perfectly.

There is no secret or magic mirror. Anything that holds water is going to generate mold and mildew. This simple mirror is light, takes up very little space, and does not need to hold water to give you plenty of time to shave when placed correctly.<br /><br />ALSO the instructions are very clear and explain exactly what you need to do to get the best results from the mirror.<br /><br />Hope this helps you decide, I know I had a lot of trouble and the reviews seemed very mixed!

  986. Fogless, just as it says in the item description. It is a little smaller than I thought it would be, but I can live with that. Good deal for the price.

  991. The mirror is made of a clear hard plastic with a reflective backing. It is small enough to be hand held, but perhaps a bit smaller than I would have liked - I had to tilt the mirror this way and that to get the correct viewing angles while shaving. It stays fog free as advertised as long as you let it heat up as instructed.<br />The instructions to heat the mirror up first are present all over the packaging and various instruction stickers, and the company even sends you an email reminding you to heat the mirror up under the water, and why you should do this. And indeed they are right. The mirror, while cold, fogged up terribly. When heated up for a bit under the shower, the fog went away entirely, and the mirror was perfectly usable.<br />I was not able to get it hot enough to remove all condensation entirely, there were still small beads of water scattered on the surface even after several minutes of direct hot water spray, but this did not affect my ability to use the mirror at all. I got a good shave in the shower, which was great. I am near-sighted and used this without glasses, so that was also a plus.
  992. Love it.... A really light weight mirror, works well in the shower. I can SEE... Not all fogged up like most mirrors
  993. If you cant figure out how to work this mirror you cant figure out how to come here to read ratings. Its not a big mirror but it easily does what it says it does. Worth the money for me.
  994. I wish this thing was just a bit wider but it works great. I shave in the shower and have dropped this thing a bunch of times with no worries.
  995. They don't lie! If you follow the instructions and let the warm water of your shower warm up BOTH sides of the mirror, it will remain fogless for quite sometime!
  996. This mirrior is much better than my last. It is not a &#34;glass&#34; mirror but certainly looks like a glass mirror. Very good quality. All you have to do is run it in the running warm water for 2-3 seconds and it wont fog up! Makes shaving in the shower great!
  997. Simply put, it works. The mount works. The mirror image is clear and crisp. And most importantly, it stays fog free for the duration of my shave.

  999. This mirror is not only inexpensive but it just works. At long last, a shave mirror that doesn't fog up on me 10 seconds into my shaving.<br /><br />Furthermore, the customer service was fantastic. Shortly after receiving the package, I somehow misplaced the hanger that sticks to the shower's glass door which is used to hold up the mirror. So, I emailed he company, asking if I could buy that part. I quickly received a response from presumably the owner who said he would send me a new one, without charge. The new part arrived the next week. A week later, the owner followed up with me to make sure that I received the part. Mind you, this service is for an inexpensive product that he probably made only a few dollars on after sending me a new part. This is a business owner who obviously cares about his product and his customers. I hope he has much success with his company; he deserves it.

  1002. When I got it I instantly noticed how relatively small it is. So before you order, make sure you look at the size in the description. When I first used it I was terribly disappointed as it does fog up. Then three days after receiving it, I get an email with a list of instructions on how to use a friggin mirror so it doesn't fog up. The instructions should've been in the box with the mirror, but lets face it no man reads the instructions anyway. Is it fog free? No, it is not. It's just a mirror. Only thing is, they teach you a common sense trick to warm up a mirror with the hot water before using it, and try not to breathe on it. Same thing I was doing with the other mirror I had. So if you already have a nifty little mirror, don't waste your money on this one. And another thing. It comes with a hook, which should be noted clearly as I spent money buying an additional pack of hooks in case it wasn't included. Wasted more money. There should be a label on the images saying &#34;hook included&#34; or a more visible noting in the description saying that theres a hook in it. I shouldn't have bought this thing.

  1005. It doesn't stay &#34;fog free&#34; for very long. I frequently have to re-wet it to get rid of the fog. On top of that, this mirror actually has a de-magnifying effect, so your face actually appears smaller in this mirror than it would in a regular mirror. I definitely would NOT recommend this mirror if you're planning to use it for shaving, plucking, eyebrow trimming, or any sort of grooming really. If you're just using it to wash your face, you're probably okay, but I think you'd be better off spending a few dollars more for a quality shower mirror as opposed to this one.

Water droplets can be cured by rubbing the mirror with a little toothpaste (just like diving masks) and it helps with some fogging. Biggest complaint is the sputtered silvered coating (assuming Aluminum) on the back has some type of plastic/epoxy coating behind it to protect it. That protective coating doesn't like either repeated moist/dry or hot/cold cycles and started flaking off after 3-4 months in the shower. Once the protective coating is off, the aluminum follows quickly after. I'm guessing I have about 6-8months left before it'll be unusable so I'll be shopping for a more protected alternative soon.

  1059. I picked up this mirror because I wanted to start shaving in the shower - I've always shaved over the sink after showering, and I wasn't all too pleased with the results. After shopping around and checking out the competition, I decided to go with this one, because the price was very reasonable and people had good things to say about it.<br /><br />When the mirror arrived, it was about as simple as I expected for the price I paid - a rounded rectangular mirror with a grey plastic-like back and a small hook to hang it with. Its appearance is certain not what I would call 'impressive', but a shower mirror is less about form and more about function, so I can't knock it for its simplicity. I wanted something that would be unobtrusive in my shower, and this mirror fits the bill just fine. The adhesive on the hook holds up great - even after a bit of tugging on it to test it out, it's pretty sturdy, certainly more than enough to support the mirror which is actually very lightweight.<br /><br />The mirror's ability to reduce fogginess is dependent on the mirror itself getting up to the temperature of your water, which is done by simply putting the grey side of the mirror underneath your shower head for a few seconds. As advertised, my mirror was fogless and shaving was a breeze. I've seen some mirrors that allow you to fill a reservoir with water to keep the mirror fogless for longer, but unless you take hour-long showers, I don't think that's really necessary.<br /><br />Overall, I definitely feel like I got my money out of my purchase, so I absolutely recommend picking this up if you're looking for a simple, effective shower mirror.
  1060. This mirror works exactly as stated. Hold it under the water a few seconds and it is fog free. Note that if you hold onto it or it's near the edge of the shower curtain and getting blasted with the colder air, it may fog a bit. It comes with a nifty hook and mounting square that, despite the humidity in the shower, has shown no sign of coming unattached. Note that it is pretty small so depending on preference, you may want something bigger. I've found it to be perfect for shaving in the shower!

  1084. This product had a lot fo positive reviews so I tried it out. Its a very small mirror so it can be a bit tricky to get a good view unless perfectly placed within close range. It comes with a nifty hanger but once you place it, it's there for good. The main selling point with this mirror is that it is &#34;fog free&#34;. Because the mirror is so small I have to get very close to it to properly shave so I can't help but fog it up. even if I don't get too close it still seems to start fogging up.   1086. I'm not sure if the original complaint is still visible or not, but this change of opinion has been long overdue. The mirror is great for up-close, fog-free, in-shower shaves, but almost more importantly, the responsibility shown by the company in ensuring I was satisfied with my purchase was as top-notch as you can find in today's day of customer service wait times, and mass-produced empty promises.<br /><br />Strongly recommend.

  1092. For those of us who prefer to shave or wash our face while showering, this shower mirror is a semi-decent product at this price point.<br /><br />It's simple to set up, and after three years of near-daily use, it's held up very well. (Their claim that it &#34;never falls&#34; is, in my experience, accurate.)<br /><br />However, I have to point out that it is anything BUT fog free. (Pls see attached photos.) It's not even close. Although there is a decent fix for the fog problem. Whenever the mirror fogs up, just rinse it under the hot shower water for a few seconds and it'll be fog free for the next 90-120 seconds. (I end up doing that between 3-6 times per shower.) Also, if you are careful to avoid breathing directly into the mirror, it greatly reduces the level of fogging.<br /><br />All in all, you get what you pay for, and this is an acceptable product at this price point.
  1093. Not only does this product actually work very well (if you do as they suggest and hold it under the water for 5 seconds or so), but the support is outstanding. I had a moment of stupidity when trying to put mine up (while also doing 12 other things) and hung it the way it had arrived in the packaging - which was upside down. Even though a bathroom remodel caused me to not even try the product for MONTHS after it arrived, when I did this and emailed support, they responded quickly, and even were willing to send out another hook with instructions. And going even further above & beyond, they followed up with another email a few days later to make sure it had worked okay. Great experience.
  1094. So I'll start off by saying the mirror definitely works. It's been a long time since I've had a mirror to shave with in the shower because every one of them would fog up after the first few uses. I typically take twenty minutes to shower and shave. I ran both sides under the warm water (to me the water seems warm compared to my wife who showers like she's cooking a lobster) at the beginning of my shower and about half way through it just barely started fogging on the edge. I didn't need it yet anyway, I just wanted to see how long it would last. I repeated the water on both sides and shaved without any problems. The size worked for me and framed my face well. I was tempted to get the larger version, but I wouldn't return it now just for the bigger size. Also it appears to be made out of plastic. Not a problem as it would suck to drop a piece of glass in the shower. But I would treat it like a pair of sunglasses and clean it with a micro-fiber cloth made for eye wear to keep it from scratching.<br /><br />Simple and effective. I would recommend to anyone.
  1095. My husband had been looking for a mirror for a long time. I found this for him and he loves it. The only thing id that after a while the piece that it hangs on came loose. We fixed it by a suction cup with a hook for it to hang on for the shower. Other then that it has been great.
  1096. If you read the directions this mirror will work perfectly for you. Just be smart.<br /><br />The directions specify that you should run the mirror under warm water to keep it from fogging up. Anyone who is having fog trouble should read the directions.
  1097. This mirror does exactly as it is advertised to do. Suction cup is very strong and has not fallen off yet.
  1098. slightly gimmicky, but good price and it works well enough. &#34;fog free&#34; lasts for 30 seconds before you have to &#34;recharge&#34; it in the hot shower water
  1099. Still using this. No major scratches and works as expected and is easy to hold.

  1102. Not really a &#34;true&#34; fogless mirror, but it does ok.
  1103. Yes, it's a fogless mirror - with some work. You have to run it under hot water to warm it up, so that condensation doesn't form on it. I've had other fogless mirrors with which you don't have to do this. And it helps to rub a little shampoo on it, which gets rid of the hundreds of water droplets on it, and makes it fogless for more than 1 shower.<br />In spite of its inconveniences, I DO like the fact that it hangs off a hook, so it's easily taken down and put back up. At the beginning of my shower, I just take it off the hook and let it sit on the tub floor around my feet while the hot water drains over it.
  1104. Use this thing every day. It's awesome.
  1105. This is a great mirror although I should have bought the larger size one. You must FOLLOW the instructions for it to work right, it's simple science anyway, temperature differential. ☺
  1106. Still works great a year later
  1107. Not recommended with hard water
  1108. Packaged as expected. It's a plastic mirror and feels sturdy so I hope it doesn't break if dropped/shattered. It's the perfect size to reflect my head and comes with a little sticky-backed hook to hang it on.<br /><br />A suggestion I would make: I've owned a different brand/type before and have some pretty heavy minerals in my water. This other one has slowly gotten &#34;water spots&#34; on it and just doesn't reflect as good as it used to. With this one, I'm going to attempt to keep it clean/dry after getting out of the shower every time to avoid that long term build-up. Then again this one may not have the same problem.
  1109. I like it a lot, but you have to keep running hot water on it every 2 minutes to keep it fog free.

It is relatively fog free after being run under hot water for a few seconds, but it is cheap.

  1119. unlike many other mirrors i have tried, this actually does not fog and presents a very clear useable image. would definitely recommend.
  1120. The mirror itself is great. It works fine and allows me to see in the shower fog free for a good deal of time. I am able to get a nice shave using this product. I am able to have it fog free for about 10-15 minutes before I would need to reheat it under running water, this is plenty of time for shave everything I need. Please note that water droplets will bead on this mirror, so you will not get a perfectly clean reflective mirror, this is really not a bother for me though. The mirror is also very sensitive to changes in temperatures. If you turn the water temp slightly up or down the mirror will start fogging again. The mirror itself is really light weight and easy to hold in the shower. It is made from acrylic and not glass, as noted in some other reviews, so it will not break from falls. I have had mine fall twice now, and the mirror is unharmed.<br /><br />The problem is the hook. It won't stay up in my shower for more than 24 hours. I cleaned the surface, I then dried the surface, I then applied the hook with the adhesive exposed and applied pressure for 20 seconds. I did this twice and both times it fell off shortly after my shower. I am applying it to a smooth tile surface, got on the grout or anything. I am trying to find some other adhesive I can attach to the hook to have it stay up in my shower.<br /><br />I think a product is only as good as its worst part, and the hook is the worst part of this product. If my mirror can't stay up, I cannot give this product a good rating. If the hook is not needed for you or you can find a workaround easily, then this is a fantastic product that I would recommend for you.<br /><br />UPDATE: The company contacted me today morning right before I submitted this review, to ask about any questions or concerns regarding this product. I explained the issue to them and responded promptly within an hour. They seem to have amazing customer service. They are sending me a new hook right away and explained to me to clean the tile surface and let it dry completely then apply the hook and let it set for 24 hours before hanging the mirror. I will try this with the new hook and will update my review again with anything new. For now I will keep my 3 star rating, but can change it depending on the service and help I receive from the company.<br /><br />UPDATE 2: The company sent me a replacement hook, an additional suction cup (which was not included in the original package), and some helpful tips. This is what they told me to do: \\"When the new hook arrives, once you have cleaned the area you plan to stick the mirror, please allow enough time for this area to completely dry (remember tile is porous and will absorb moisture from your cleaning solution). For best results, let the adhesive \\"set\\" for 24 hours before hanging the mirror on the hook.\\" It is a little bit of extra effort to make sure the tile is completely dry and the hook is set for a whole 24 hours before hanging the mirror, but it really does help. I cleaned my tile with tile cleaner, as I had done previously, and let it dry for about 30 to 60 minutes, I then press the hook adhesive to the tile for 20 seconds and let it \\"set\\" for 20 hours before hanging a mirror on it. So far it has been up for 3 days without falling off. If it does fall off again I will update my review with how long it stayed up. To be honest though I prefer the suction cup they sent me to hang my mirror. It is easier to install, stays up just as well as the hook (if not better), and can be repositioned anytime you need. I wish it were included in the original package.<br /><br />I have raised my review to 5 stars because I am now satisfied with the product. The hook may still not be perfect; it takes more effort than expected to attach to your tile, and can't be repositioned. But the customer service I received for a $10 product has been out of this world. It seems to me that they are 100% committed to make your product meet your needs. This service is far more of a positive than any negative of the hook.ositive than any negative of the hook.

  1130. I originally purchased this mirror in 2011 for my husband and within just a few months the backing began chipping off. The gentleman kept in contact with me to see if the new one was working for us. Unfortunately it did begin chipping again, but we found through communicating with him that it was because of the salt in our water from our water softener. The manufacturer is working on resolving this problem. In the meantime, we will continue to use this mirror and purchase again if we have to because it is such a great lightweight design that is truly fog-free if you follow instructions.   1132. performs just as advertised, like the hole to hang it anywhere you want to. Just keep it warm and it works like magic
  1133. Believe it or not, this is the first fog-free shower shave mirror I've used. Well, that's not totally true. It's not that this never fogs - it's just incredibly easy to prevent the fog from showing up for a long time, and to eliminate it if it does show up. Just run the mirror under the shower water for a few seconds, and you're good to go.<br /><br />This is also a great size. I know they make a larger version if you so desire, but I find that I end up getting so close to the mirror to see what I'm shaving that a bigger mirror surface would be wasted. Plus, this mirror is small enough to toss in my toiletries bag when I have to travel. Perfect.<br /><br />Finally, this is also the mirror with the most easily prevented water spots. The instructions that came with the mirror suggest using toothpaste to remove water spots. I disagree. That might work, but I've never had to try. Instead, I suggest preventing the water spots from showing up in the first place. It's really easy to do. Just dry the mirrored surface off with your towel after you shower, then hang it back up backwards (mirrored side facing the wall). Next time you need to shave, you'll have to take the mirror off the hook to run it under the water anyway, so just flip it back around at that point. In the meantime, it doesn't collect water spots!
  1134. First one I've purchased that actually does what it says it will do. You do have to run it under hot water when you begin your shower for it to work properly. After I did that, it worked as promised. Great product, excellent value. I recommend it.
  1135. I have been using this mirror for the past five months and so far i have been really happy with it. All you have to do is run it under the shower for a few seconds to prevent fogging. A lot of times it fogs up halfway through my shave, but i just run it under the shower again an it clears up. Basically, this is a simple and low cost solution to shaving in the shower.
  1136. This shower mirror does what it is supposed to: provide a good reflected image while staying fog free. I liked it enough, I bought a second one to take along when I travel.
  1137. I was actually kind of surprised at how well this worked. It didn't fog up at all. If you want something for the shower, this is a good buy.

  1140. Handy enough to use, but takes a few seconds to preheat. Problem is that if the mirror rests against a tile wall it soon gets cold again and fogs up. Wouldn't buy it again unless that change were made AND my shower stall wasn't lined with tile or marble.
